title: Episode remains in miniplayer upon feed deletion
body:
When a feed is deleted (for example from the feed overview) and an episode of that feed is paused and present in the miniplayer, it is not removed from the miniplayer: the episode remains visible and the miniplayer becomes kind of unresponsive (i.e.: pressing it does nothing).

I guess it would be nice to remove the miniplayer from the screen in this situation.

title: Export favourites
label: [Label(name="good first issue")]
body:
I recently upgraded from Android 5 to 6 and that didn't go as planned. I backed up most of my data, but unfortunately manual export of the favourites isn't possible. So I lost them. Not a massive big deal, but a pity though. It would be great to be able to export favourites as well, just as one can export the subscribed feeds (through OMPL). I could imagine it being json, html, xml, ...?

Since some feeds (or at least their files) quite sometimes disappear from the interwebs (as is the case with quite some BBC feeds), it would be nice if one could also choose to include the audio files.

title: The 1.6.3.0 update broke use of custom AntennaPod icons in icon packs
body: After the update to 1.6.3.0 icon packs containing custom AntennaPod icons no longer get them applied. Unless you use a launcher where you can set individual custom icons you are now stuck with default icon for AntennaPod. I know this is only cosmetic, but since AntennaPod is one of my most used apps it matters.

title: Repeating app crashes on Android 7.x
body:
Hi,

i am using AntennaPod on my phone since several month. While running vanialla (moto-version) Android 6.x it was stable and worked as expected - as a result i really love this application as it covers whatever i need from a podcast app.

Since upgrading to Android 7.x (Lineage) i got the impression that AntennaPod is running pretty unstable for me. I found similar problem reports in the Google Play comments concerning Antennapod stability issues on Android 7.

**Some crash examples:**
* App is crashing while downloading new episodes
* App is crashing while playing


**Crashes might happen in different styles:**
* App is silently closed (usually when display is off)
* App is crashing showing an Android dialog that antennapod was closed offering option to reopen it or ignore until next boot (usually when display is on/active while crash happens)
* App is crashing as part of a soft-reboot of the device (usually when playing and display is off)

To get a better impression about the run-times between crashes i'll add an example/excerpt of my today crashes

**Example crash history**
* 16:58 - App closed silenty while playing with display off
* 16:59 - App closed silenty while playing with display off
* 17:00 - App closed silenty while playing with display off
I was wondering if it changes if i do have the display running/on - so i kept using the phone for the following minutes
* 17:07 - App closed with OS crash dialog while display was on
* 17:12 - App closed with OS crash dialog while display was on
Back to having display off
* 17:18 - App closed silenty while playing with display off
* 17:19 - App closed silenty while playing with display off
* 17:20 - App closed silenty while playing with display off


**App version:** 
1.6.2.3 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 
7.1.2 [Lineage]

**Devide model**: 
Moto G 2015 - Osprey

**Expected behaviour**:
Antennapod should play episodes without crashing

**Current behaviour**:
Antennapod is crashing

**First occured**: 
According to my impression it started since Android 7.x

**Steps to reproduce**:
Hard to tell, usually i am really just listening to something having the display off.


**Environment**: 
* Episodes are stored on external sd card (tried 2 different cards so far)


**Stacktrace/Logcat**: 
I do have a logcat output of this crashes mentioned above, please tell me if you want the full, or just :W, :E or :F to reduce the logcat clutter.

I would love to offer any additional information needed and help as far as i can. Please let me know whatelse might help you.

**Android version**: 7.1.2 (LineageOS April Build)

**Devide model**: Samsung Galaxy S4 i9505

**Expected behaviour**: Progress bar should show the current playback position after reopening the app

**Current behaviour**: Playback progress bar is completely filled

1. Kill the app (it must be completely stopped)

When you tap on the progress bar and then go back the playback position is set properly

**Environment**: only difference to default is night theme

**Stacktrace/Logcat**: n/a

title: Resume downloads if service was killed
body:
If the download service is killed by Android or a taskmanager, restarting the download creates a second file. The old one stays in the media folder without any reference in the database. 

As suggested by mfietz, the `downloaded` field in the DB should be expanded to allow persisting the state of started downloads.

title: Atom feed subscription fails when there is no default namespace
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (from Google Play)

title: Better control of pause/lower volume on interruptions
body:
I have noticed lately that some videogames either lower the volume of playback (I think they use whatever signal is captured on option "Pause for interruptions") or even pause playback (I don't know how they do this). An example of the second can be seen here: https://us.battle.net/forums/en/hearthstone/topic/20749088203.

My suggestion would be to add a more granular control of to what events from other apps is AntennaPod responding to and what should it do: ignore, lower volume or pause.

I just had to search a minute to find out why the podcast has "Filtered" written on top of it (it was not filtered, but adding and removing a filter removed the message). So I think the filter icon should be easier to recognize as such.

title: Unable to start downloaded podcasts with no WiFi/Cell service
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (commit: e7c69534)

**Android version**: 7.1.1 (March 5, 2017 security patch)

**Devide model**: Nexus 5X

**Expected behaviour**: Should be able to start playing downloaded podcasts while offline

**Current behaviour**: Unable to start a downloaded podcast with no WiFi/Cell signal

**First occured**: Since I've been using, about 6 months ago

**Steps to reproduce**:

1. Download podcast while on WiFi
2. Go to area with no WiFi or cell Service (tunnels, subways)
3. Open App and go to Queue
4. Select unplayed podcast to play
5. Podcast does not start
6. Can only start podcast once cell signal or on WiFi

**Work Around**: If I start a downloaded podcast before losing a signal, I can play it while out of service. For example:

1. Download podcast
2. Play first couple seconds of downloaded Podcast
3. Pause Podcast
4. Go to place with no signal
5. Resume downloaded podcast.

**Environment**: Background data for app disallowed via Android settings. Automatic Downloads off. Mobile Updates off.

title: Image loading is in the main thread
body:
Dear developers,
I found some images are loaded in the main thread in AntennaPod.

For image loading, Google says this:
https://developer.android.com/topic/performance/graphics/index.html
" Loading bitmaps on the UI thread can degrade your app's performance, causing slow responsiveness or even ANR messages."

I noticed that in the following code, image loading is in worker thread:
https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/service/playback/PlaybackService.java
de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.playback.PlaybackService.java   run()  (line number: 1159)
(bitmap is loaded with the invocation of decodeResource ())

However, in the code below, image loading is in the main thread: 
https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/service/download/DownloadService.java
(1) de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.download.DownloadService.java   setupNotificationBuilders()   (line number: 340 )
(bitmap is loaded with the invocation of decodeResource ())
which is called by  de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.download.DownloadService.java  onCreate()

(2) de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.download.DownloadService.java  updateReport()   (line number: 546)
(bitmap is loaded with the invocation of decodeResource ())
which is called by  de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.download.DownloadService.java  onDestroy()

I am curious about the latter cases. Why these image loading operations are in main thread? 

Do you think perform image loading in the main thread will affect AntennaPod's performance? If so, perhaps moving the images loading to a work thread can help make app more smooth in user interaction.
Looking forward to your response.

Thanks.

title: Inefficient API is used
body:
Dear developers,

I found an inefficient API, setImageResource(), is used in AntennaPod.

For setImageResource(), Google says this:
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/widget/ImageView.html
" This does Bitmap reading and decoding on the UI thread, which can cause a latency hiccup. If that's a concern, consider using setImageDrawable(android.graphics.drawable.Drawable) or setImageBitmap(android.graphics.Bitmap) and BitmapFactory instead. "

I noticed that in the following code, setImageResource() is used:
de.danoeh.antennapod.core.util.playback.PlaybackController.java  (lineNumber: 484 )
 https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/util/playback/PlaybackController.java

Do you think the use of setImageResource() will affect AntennaPod's performance? If so, maybe we should move Bitmap reading and decoding to a background thread.

Thanks.

title: Bluetooth crashes as soon as I press play
body:
Hi AntennaPod team,

**Problem:**
Bluetooth crashes as soon as I press play. "Unfortunately, Bluetooth has stopped." Behavior still occurs when Bluetooth is just on and not connected to any other device. If I close the app and restart, the problem occurs again. If I restart the phone, the problem still occurs again. I have (multiple times) cleared cache and data for the Bluetooth app and tried again, and the behavior still occurs.
This behavior is limited to AntennaPod. Bluetooth does not crash during operation of other audio player apps such as Poweramp or stock music app.

**Expected:**

title: Remove silence in podcast episodes
label: [Label(name="feature request"), Label(name="good first issue")]

title: Handle slow/unresponsive podcast feeds
body:
This is a feature request. For podcast feeds that are slow or temporarily unresponsive, Antennapod currently freezes and becomes unresponsive until the offending feed responds. Even killing Antennapod via Android's task switcher doesn't always clear the issue since it seems Antennapod tries to resume the last download it was performing before it was killed.

Ideally, it would be nice to have some sort of twiddler graphic to show Antennapod is still running, and hasn't gotten stuck due to some low memory issue, as well as some sort of cancel button for the current operation so if a podcast feed is down, you can cancel it and allow Antennapod to skip to the next feed. The app does currently show a progress bar and cancel button when the download or stream begins, but the issue here is happening before the download begins. The initial connection is timing out and Antennapod doesn't appear to check for this and hangs indefinitely.

I track a couple dozen podcasts, and this is making it very frustrating to use Antennapod because if even one feed is down, it means I can't use Antennapod. If I accidentally click on an item for a feed that's down, now Antennapod freezes for 10 minutes until I kill it.

An easy way to reproduce this problem is to setup a wireless router not connected to the Internet, connect to it's wifi, and then attempt to use Antennapod to stream or download a item on one of your existing feeds. The app will freeze and hang indefinitely and not report any status, forcing you to kill it.

**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 5.1.1 (CyanogenMod 12.1)

**Device model**: HTC One M7

title: Add more playback control options for hardware buttons
body:
The current default behavior of forward and backward hardware buttons is to fast-forward/rewind, and the user can change this behavior in preferences by enabling 'Forward button skips' or 'Previous button restarts'.

This change adds the ability to assign new actions to these hardware controls. The full set of options would be:

- Skip to the next/previous episode
- Fast forward/Rewind
- Increase/Decrease playback speed
- Restart episode (backward button only)

The default behavior would not changed, the hardware buttons will still fast-forward/rewind. The older toggle preferences have been removed so that multiple options could be supported, but if either of them were enabled the equivalent behavior will be chosen for the new preferences.

In addition, the user can choose to perform any of the custom behaviors listed above if a button is double-tapped.

Closes #2247

Screencast of new preferences: https://gfycat.com/TameUnitedKoalabear

title: Introduce "continuous playback in subscription queue"
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (from F-Store)

**Android version**: 6.0.1

**Devide model**: Nexus 5

**Expected behaviour**: podcast streamed from a subscription queue - end of podcast - next podcast from the same subscription starts automatically. 

**Current behaviour**: 
- First option : podcast streamed from a subscription queue - end of podcast - top queue podcast starts (if cotinuous playback is enabled)
- Second option : podcast streamed from a subscription queue - end of podcast - nothing plays next (if continuous playback is disabled)

I think each podcast's list of each subscription could be considered as an independent queue, so that we could sort the the podcasts (date, duration for example) and play continuously all the podcasts of a same subscription in the sorted order, even if some podcasts in the list are not in the main queue. A "continuous playback in subscription queue" option could be implemented in the settings.

Thanks for reading! 
What do you think?

title: Skip and seek with a single set of forward/backward hardware buttons
body:
I'm currently on version 1.6.2.3

I'd like to have an easy way to change episodes in the car without picking up my phone. I can enable the 'Forward button skips' preference, but it doesn't let you go backwards in the queue and it removes the ability to fast-forward (which is a nice feature since my car does not have separate fast-forward/rewind buttons).

My proposal is to support both fast-forward/rewind and skip to next/previous at the same time by assigning one action to a single tap, and the other to a double tap. e.g., If the user presses 'forward' once, then it fast-forwards. If they press it twice quickly, it skips to the next track.

I've implemented this locally to test the idea, and it works well for my use case so I'm interested in what other people think. The double tap works by waiting a small amount of time after a forward/backward request to see if another request comes in. If it does, it skips to the next/previous episode. If it doesn't, it performs the user's original request (reset to 0, ff/rw, etc.)

title: Time link parsing
body:
Some podcasts do the time codes in the descriptions instead of real chapters. [AntennaPod](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/util/playback/Timeline.java#L128) seems to only match HH:MM:SS and not MM:SS, or only the first? In this [feed, latest episode](http://cast.rocks/hosting/2041/feeds/CQMQA.xml) the first is matched as HH:MM not MM:SS and no others are.

Also maybe they could be added to the chapters interface? The chapter title could be based on the text in the tag where the match was found, but I could see how parsing that would get messy.

title: Possible places to store the episodes?
body:
Hi,

My exact problem is very simple: When I go to Preferences > Storage > Choose directory (Sorry I'm translating, so the names might not be exactly those in the English version...) and tap on the current directory path, I get a pop up, with a radio button with only a single choice: the default storage location. I am thus totally unable to change the directory where to store the files. Why is that so?

Within the issues already listed here, I found a few about the directory where to store the files and SDCards. They're about setting this dir on the SDCard then removing the SDCard. Reading this I imagined that you have disabled the possibility to change the dir to prevent this kind of bug. Is is the case?
The other possibility I see is that I'm under Android 4.2.2, and I read there were problems with this version and access rights on the SDCard. However, my other apps can access the card without any problem... So I'm just stuck....

Any idea how I can put the downloaded podcasts into the SDCard instead of filling my device's internal memory?

title: Feature Request: Pause when GPS is speaking
body:
**Use Case**
When driving with Google Maps voice on, AntennaPod does not pause when the GPS speaks. This makes it difficult to follow the podcast.

**Implementation**
When any audio is detected, pause AntennaPod and rewind 5 seconds.

title: Feature Request: Save to Music folder
body:
**Use Case**: I listen to mostly music podcasts of DJ sets and sometimes want to listen to an episode many times. I would like to be able to save the podcast to my music folder. This is similar to the "Favorite" feature in function, but I would prefer to have the files I want to keep long term in the same location as all my other music. It also seems safer and more permanent to me - sometimes I'll find an abandoned podcast and want to save some of the episodes, but I'm not sure if I remove the podcast (since it never updates and doesn't need to be checked anymore) if I will lose the starred episodes when the podcast subscription is deleted. I think the separation makes sense - podcast client is for listening to new episodes, most of which I don't want to save. Music app and folder are for music I will keep long-term.

**Implementation**

1. One possibility I see would be to add the function to the 'Share' functionality. An option of "Save this episode to Music folder" would be added. Selecting this would copy the episode file to the Music folder. Arguably it doesn't fit the word 'Share" very well but since other app share buttons often go to services like Instapaper that provide personal archiving it seems like it wouldn't be too confusing or unobvious.

2. A second possibility would be to make this the optional behavior of the 'Favorite' function - clicking the star causes the file to copied to the Music folder. However, then the question is raised of what to do when the episode is unstarred, and whether the copy of the file in the Music folder should stay there or not.

**Issues**: I'm not an Android developer, so I don't know if the Music folder is a universal concept among all Android versions and flavors. It might require a setting to select the appropriate folder.

title: Android automatic refactor - ObsoleteLayoutParam
body:
Hi,

I am developing a tool to automatically refactor Android applications with the goal of improving energy efficiency.
This pull request has the changes generated while applying the rule "ObsoleteLayoutParam".

While developing your application's views you might be specifying attributes in a view's artefact that are not necessary due to the nature of its parent. In this PR, those attributes were replaced by a comment.

I have made a previous validation of the changes and they seem correct.
Unfortunately, this tool is not able keep the original whitespace of the files, so comparison without ignoring whitespace might be confusing.
Please consider the changes and let me know if you agree with them.

Best,
Luis

title: Update feed URLs to https if possible
body:
In December 2016 Apple adds support for Lets Encrypt Certificates on Podcast Feeds
https://feed.press/blog/2016/12/16/apple-silently-adds-support-lets-encrypt-certificates-podcast-feeds/

A few podcasts are already switching to https and hopefully there will be more in the near future.
Some of them are redirecting the http feed to https with HTTP-Status 301 or 302 and sadly some of them have no redirection to the https feed.

But at the moment it's not possible to change the feed URL from http to https in AntennaPod, so it would be nice to be able to edit the feed URL or maybe to have an option to be able to check if the feed is available with https and edit the feed URL automatically.

**App version:** 1.6.2.3

**Android version**: 7.1.1 (latest CyanogenMod version 14.1-20161225-NIGHTLY-hammerhead)

**Devide model**: Google Nexus 5

title: Stream resets to last playback time / Progress Bar doesn't
label: [Label(name="needs info")]
body:
--- Stream resets to last playback time / Progress Bar doesn't
I've encountentered this bug multiple times in the last few weeks. It is quiet similiar to #1264 and #345 , yet even worse. What happens: - I paused a podcast at Point A, do something else, then resume playing - it sometimes plays from the last position Point B, I paused the podcast, similar to #1264. BUT the progress bar doesn't reset to that position Point B, but continues at Point A. This means at that point, the actual stream and the GUI are inconsistent. There are 2 things that can happen if i now skip to a point prior to Point A: - The whole episode is skipped, marked as finished and the next episode in my queue plays. - It plays the right point of the stream again However, regardless if it now is playing the right way again, if i skip to any point posterior to Point A, it will always reset to Point B again, without matching the progress bar. If i skip to a point prior to A, let i play beyond A, it plays normally, but I can still not skip to a point beyond A. **Android version**: 6.0.1 **Devide model**: OnePlus Two **First occured**: about a month ago **Steps to reproduce**: 1. Play something 1. Pause. Use another App (maybe call someone or listen to something else in another app) 1. Resume **Environment**: If often switch my phone to flight mode at night, which causes the app to fail some automatic downloads.

title: Enhanced Automatic Download Settings
body:
Ability to set default auto download settings globally for all subscriptions. Right now, if I want to turn on automatic download, it's on for all my subscriptions and I have to go into those I do not want to be included in automatic download and turn them off one by one. I'd much rather turn it on for each subscription selectively than turning it on for all and shutting off those I do not want to include. 

Also, an option for the episode cache to be "1", with daily episodes automatically downloaded, it would make sense. I know I'm not going back and listening to something that is 5 days old when there is a new episode today.

title: Detached streaming thread
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 from F-Droid

**Android version**: 6.0.1 / CyanogenMod 13.0

**Device model**: [Moto E](https://wiki.cyanogenmod.org/w/Condor_Info)

**Expected behaviour**:
No matter where a podcast is playing from, only one should be playing at one time, and the UI controls should always control that single podcast.

One way to trigger this seems to be, but it's unreliable.

**Current behaviour**:

The thread that streams a podcast seems to be able to find itself detached from the UI. The symptoms of this are:

- another podcast can play over top of the streaming podcast
- the controls in the notifications drawer and on the main UI control the second one and there is no way to stop the first one
- swiping AntennaPod away from the recent apps list immediately makes the faulty player stop.

**First occured**: at least a year ago. But it is hard to reproduce so I never bothe

**Steps to reproduce**:

I cannot figure out how to reproduce this reliably.  I have seen it happen multiple times so I'm sure it's real, but it's intermittent.  It seems to happen more readily when I've been messing with the storage location for downloaded episodes (e.g., after my SD card dies and I've gotten a new one), which then makes AntennaPod confused about what episodes it should list the stream button instead of the delete button for, which then leads to me button mashing a lot of play commands in to all the episodes to get AntennaPod to resync its state with what's on disk.  My best guess is that the problem happens if I order an episode to stream S then manage to play an episode from disk D before the stream S connects (before the syn/ack gets through?): then S connects and starts playing, but the UI is now attached to D.

title: Feature to NOT add new episodes to play queue
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 4.1.2

**Device model**: Samsung Galaxy Ace 2 GT-I8160 (UK)

**Expected behaviour**: When a new episode is published, AntennaPod checks a configuration element to see whether it should be added to the play "Queue". Only add to the play queue if this option is enabled, otherwise perform other configured actions, e.g. download but do not add to play queue.

**Current behaviour**: All new (downloaded?) episodes are added to the play queue.

**Justification for feature request**: I have a wide range of podcasts that are configured to automatically download new episodes as they are published. When I decide to listen to podcasts, I want to chose the episodes that I want to listen to which may not necessarily be all the podcasts downloaded, e.g. I may want to listen to some comedy on my walk to the station in the morning but a drama on the train journey home in the evening. I want to define the play list for my listening manually.

**Proposed implementation**: I suggest a global Boolean configuration element, "Automatically add to play queue". This could be asserted by default to retain current behaviour, i.e. not change default behaviour of application. It may be advantageous to add a per-subscription option to override the global setting but I think the global setting is required. (My preferred workflow is to have no podcasts added to the play queue by default.) This setting may best be placed in the "QUEUE" section of the settings menu. (The settings menu is rather long so it may prove advantageous to add a sub-menu for queue management but that is not the subject of the feature request.)

title: Download continued over Mobile Data after wifi signal was lost
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Today I stopped to get a coffee, left my phone in the car.  I had cleared my queue to make room for new downloads.  It connected to starbucks wifi and started to auto download recent subscribed podcasts.  It lost wifi connection, but continued to download over mobile data, even though 'Mobile Updates' was toggled off.  I did not have a wifi filter on, allowing it to connect to all wifi networks, I would assume.  I have downloads scheduled for 2am nightly.

Should it not have stopped downloading once it lost wifi?  It cost me $40 in data overages.

Thanks.

---

**App version:** 1.6.2.3

**Android version**: 6.0.1 (no custom rom)

**Devide model**: Galaxy S5 SM-G900W8

**Expected behaviour**:  Only download podcasts over wifi.

**Current behaviour**:   Downloaded podcasts over data network

**First occured**: This is not the first time it has happened.  Noticed about 6 months ago.

**Steps to reproduce**:  

1. Empty full queue
2. connect to wifi network
3. available podcasts begin download
4. lost wifi connection
5. download continues over data network.  No way to terminate.

**Environment**: 

**Stacktrace/Logcat**: 
```
[if available]
```

title: Statistics are not accurate
label: [Label(name="duplicate")]
body:
I have been noticing this with several podcasts since the statistics feature was introduced, but was waiting for a very good example to be sure  got one now :)

I have just started a new podcast I listened to the trailer and two episodes  one of 44min and the other of 36min  and started a few seconds of another one. I only ever listen at 1.0 speed.

The statistics tab, for that podcast, indicate 3.5 hours. Tapping the podcast indicates  4 out of 10 episodes started. Played 3.5 hours out of 2.1 hours. .

I really do not see where these numbers would come from. When listening to podcasts, I very very often rewind 15s or so and was thinking this may me confusing the counters, but for this particular podcast, I listened to both episodes in one go.

Found another example : a podcast where I only listened to the trailer (1.30min) and to the first 15 minutes of the first episode (of 39min). The statistics indicate  2 out of 5 episodes started. Played 1.2 hours out of 0.7 hours. . Same, only 1.0 speed, no rewinds, no re-listens.

Since I use gpodder I can probably extract from the API my exact listening patterns of these two examples if that helps.

Let me know if I can provide more information!

---

**App version:** 1.6.2.2 (from F-Store)

**Android version**: 5.1.1

**Devide model**: Samsung Galaxy S5 mini (SM-G800F)

title: AP orphans playback after removal from queue
body:
**App version:** 1.6.2.3 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 5.1 Fairphone

**Devide model**: Fairphone 1

**Expected behaviour**: Stop playback, remove episode from queue, delete the file and remove mini-player

**Current behaviour**: item is removed from the queue, playback continues, mini-player dis- and reappears. When reappeared one can press play to initiate a second playback that 'overlays' the original one. Playback is stopped when the screen is swiped away from the multitask screen.


**First occured**: Dunno, but didn't happen always.

**Steps to reproduce**:

1. Have a 'full' queue, initiate playback
2. While playing, delete the item from the queue

**Environment**: So the queue is full; automatic deletion is off but auto-clean-up is set to remove episodes when they're not in the queue. Ergo,: the item gets deleted from the queue and the playback process seems 'orphaned', making it possible to initiate a second playback (of the same file which is still displayed in the mini-player & notification) which 'overlays' the playback that was running before deletion.

title: More rules to exclude episodes
body:
Hello,
In the podcast settings, we can precise some terms to include and/or exclude episodes from the auto-download. i thinks it would be nice if there were more rules available (filters on length,size,release date, ...). 

For example, I follow a science french show called "La Tte au Carr" where each episode is around 1 hour long and devided into two part : A short one (10 min) and a long one (50 min). The problem is, the short ones parts are also present in the feed and thus are downloaded automatically. To not listen two time to the same info, I have to delete them manually every time from the queue and, then, from the intern storage. 
If I could exclude all episodes shorter than 11min, it would be great. 

I know it's a very specific feature but I don't think it is difficult to implement

title: Show play time after applying speed
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Sometimes I'd like to choose a podcast episode based on how long it will take. I also use *speed* setting to speed up the playback.

It would be nice to show adjusted time after applying the speed. In other words, show the "[wallclock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall-clock_time)" time for the total episode length and/or for the remaining time left.

For instance, if the speed is set to `2.00`, a 10-minute episode could show 5 minutes of total playback time. If the playback is at the 2-minute mark, then it could show the remaining playback time of 4 minutes (8 "virtual" minutes remaining).

Where to show this information? At the playback controls, it can be below the speed number, or right above the seek bar. This time can also be shown at the queue or at the episode list, but it can get very confusing, so I'm not sure if it is a good idea.

title: Upgrade okhttp to version 3
Loudness normalization (compressor/limiter)
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Some podcasts have wildly varying audio levels. It can be quite unpleasant to listen to them via headphones -- either you don't understand what's being said, or your ears start to hurt. This is also a health risk.

In technical terms, this is an issue of missing normalization during postproduction of the podcasts, or postproduction for a different target: Attentive listeners with a Hifi rack and speakers can appreciate voices talking softly and shouting alternately, while people with headphones, sitting on a train, jogging, or listening on car audio while driving can not. 

A basic audio effect can go a long way to fix this: We need a compressor, to push up the soft parts, and a limiter, to keep the loud parts within bounds.

There are some quite sophisticated solutions for this, e.g. auphonic. A good introduction in their blog: https://auphonic.com/blog/2011/07/25/loudness-normalization-and-compression-podcasts-and-speech-audio/

For Android, this opensource app seems to offer a normalization feature:
http://vipersaudio.com/blog/

I have also found this free compressor which focuses on PD apps:
http://cdm.link/2013/12/free-open-source-compressor-built-pd-perfect-mobile/

and this one, which is only "free as in beer" for use in apps:
http://superpowered.com/compressor-limiter-clipper#compressor

title: Episodes sometimes skipped and deleted mid-episode with no input
body:
App version: 1.6.1.2 (from Google Play)
Android version: 6.0.1
Device model: Samsung Galaxy S7
Expected behaviour: podcasts should not intermittently be skipped and deleted while partway through.
Current behaviour: occasionally a podcast will be playing, then suddenly the next podcast in the queue starts playing even though the previous one hadn't finished. The interrupted episode is removed from the queue and deleted from the device.
First occurred: three weeks ago
Environment: "keep skipped episodes" is on, so it's definitely not that the skip button is accidentally being pressed. "Auto delete" is on, so possibly it thinks that playback has completed when it hasn't. "Sonic media player" is on. Always using normal (non-bluetooth) headphones.

This has happened to me repeatedly over the last several weeks, with various different podcast feeds.

This issue seems to have come up a couple of times in the past:
https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/1644 (issue apparently went away)
https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/1162 (blamed on bluetooth headphones but not with much evidence)

I never saw this behaviour on my old phone (an ancient Galaxy S2). Happy to install a debug version of the app to try to catch the problem.

title: Items removed from queue/device prematurely when using chromecast
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2

**Android version**: 6.0.1, stock version from Verizon

**Devide model**: Galaxy S5

**Expected behaviour**: Episode stays in queue when starting on Chromecast. Episodes should only be deleted from queue or the device if I have finished the episode.

**Current behaviour**: If you end one podcast while viewing on Chromecast and hit play on the next podcast, the new episode will play, but it disappears from the Queue, and is also deleted from the phone.

**First occured**: I first noticed this a few days or a week ago, but I generally only cast to Chromecast once a week.

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Play one podcast episode.
2. Cast it to a chromecast
3. When the episode ends, immediately start another episode (let's call it episode B) by pressing play on an item in your Queue.
4. Episode B will begin playing on the Chromecast, however- Episode B will be removed from the Queue and will be deleted from the device. If I stop casting in the middle of episode B and expect to come back and finish it on my phone later, I am out of luck. I have to re-download the episode on my phone again (if I even remember that I had that episode to finish).

**Environment**: Nothing I can think of.

**Stacktrace/Logcat**: 
None. If there is something i can do, to provide you more info, let me know.

title: Statistics page time dillation effect
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2 Google Play

**Android version**: 6.0.1 CyanogenMod

**Devide model**: Moto G 4G 2014

The Statistics page shows I've spent 5.4 hours listening to a podcast when I've only spent <3 hours. There were three episodes. The first two I listened at varying speeds 1x to 1.4x. After the first two (2 hours), it showed I'd listened to 3.6 hours. The third episode I listened on 1x speed all the way through and it still bumped from 3.6 to 5.4 hours.

I can see this occurring with all the podcasts, not just one. I do usually switch speeds when listening, so I'm mostly listening to greater than 1x speed.

**First occured**: this week (I just installed AntennaPod)

**Environment**:  Sonic media player

Let me know if you need anything else. Cheers!

title: Pause, Jump Forward, and Playback Speed buttons stop working
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2 (from F-Droid)

**Android version**: 6.0.1

**Device model**: Nexus 6

**Expected behaviour**: Pause, Jump Forward (30 s), Playback Speed buttons in the 'Now Playing' window and notification window do their intended function

**Current behaviour**: The jump forward button work from one to a dozen times and then stops working, additionally the pause button stops working. This means if the audio is playing I need to Force Stop the app.  The buttons do give the animation effect that they are being pressed when I tap them even though they do not work.

**First occured**: At least 3 months ago, I believe even longer.

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Open app
2. Press play beside an item in the queue
3. Press the jump forward button 1-12 times
4. None of these buttons (jump forward, pause) work anymore

Note that it seems I can pause and play the podcast many times and that it is only the jump forward button that causes this problem.

I have tried multiple podcasts that all have this effect.

I am not sure if it is related, but the playback speed should change when I tap it but it does not.  When I long press it, I can see I have selected the speeds I want but tapping it does not cycle through them.

**Environment**: Nothing special

Thanks!

title: feed files can pile up in the directory files/cache
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 6.0

**Expected behaviour**: Only one feed file per subscription in the files/cache directory.

**Current behaviour**: If you have two subscriptions that share the same name, then every time the feeds are downloaded, the file "feed-${PODCASTNAME}" is updated and a file named "feed-${PODCASTNAME}-${I++}." is added to files/cache wasting many megabytes after a while. If you have three subscriptions with the same name, two additional files are created. If you have four, three ...

TIA for fixing!

title: Visual distinction for queue items with auto download disabled
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
I usually have a large number of episodes downloaded. However, sometimes I realise I've gone a bit overboard and downloaded too many, and there's not enough space for other stuff.

I can go through and delete some of the downloaded episodes, however this means that the episode is marked to not auto download. I can long press on the items to re-enable auto download of those episodes, but it would be useful if there were some way to distinguish episodes that have been disabled.

title: Feature request: accounts
body:
Currently I am subscribed to a bunch of podcasts for myself, but also a bunch of educational ones for my young kids. AntennaPod though gives me no easy to distinguish which should be played, short of only playing podcasts from one source.

Similarly, when I'm sitting on the sofa at home, often I'd like to watch some of my video podcasts, however, when I'm driving, I'd prefer to not be distracted by video based content. Similarly again, when I'm working, I'd really rather only have my music based podcasts playing. In short, often I would like to be able to play podcasts from one group of sources, rather than all of them or just one.

In contrast, Netflix let's me create a separate "account" which is essentially just a name, an image and a separate dataset for what's been watched etc. On opening the Netflix app, it just asks who's watching (if there's more than one account) and adjusts what is displayed accordingly.

My request is to set up a similar function on AntennaPod. The ability to create accounts would be done from the settings with an "Add an account" button, which would then let users enter a name and choose an image (with a random one assigned to begin with).

I have art/design skills (I'm the lead artist on The Secret Chronicles gpl game here on GitHub) so I'd be happy to help with creating a new set of profile image designs if needed.

Accounts would each have their own list of subscribed podcasts, settings and records of what has been listened to/watched. Each account could also be marked as an administrator or not, which would allow changing settings and adding/removing podcasts.

The advantage of an"accounts" based ui rather than something like subfolders, is the simplicity of being able to choose a source by simply tapping on a large, easy to hit button on startup, without slide out windows and scrolling etc. My kids can easily open Netflix, choose their account and hit play in a way they couldn't easily open AntennaPod and play a specific podcast right now. Similarly, if I'm trying to get a specific set of podcasts playing in a couple of seconds while waiting in my car at the lights, I could open AntennaPod, choose an account and hit play, where I'd be very lucky to open AntennaPod, pull out the slider window, scroll to a folder of podcasts only 1em high, tap that and then hit play... before the lights turned green.

Anyway, thanks for considering this. AntennaPod is already an amazing podcast client. For me, this would likely evolve it past that, to my family's primary media source. <3

title: Parsing clean up
body:
[Alternative feeds](http://podlove.org/alternate-feeds/) is currently against spec, so I added support for it to be done through an archives link. Still supports alternate links as that's what's used and currently still recommended.

Adds images from media:content, if its medium, mime type or file extension indicates an image. I also cleaned up some of the mime type stuff when it is not present in RSS, MRSS or Atom. I've never seen this but it's presumably in their for a reason.

Also adds support for multiple authors.

title: OPML Import is not working from SD card
body:
---

It is impossible to import subscriptions from OPML file from SD card.
The following error message is displayed:
"Access to external storage is required to read the OPML file." with two buttons "Cancel" and "OK".
If you press "Cancel", the message disappears.
If you click "OK", it disappears for a short time and promptly appears again.

Should permissions be added for external storage access?

---

**App version:** 1.6.1.0, 1.6.1.2, 1.5.2.0

**Android version**: 2.3.4

**Device model**: LG P690

**Environment**: Rooted device, No Google Play Services installed

**Expected behaviour**: List of subscriptions from OPML file is displayed

**Current behaviour**: Error is displayed

**First occured**: Version 1.6.1.0

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Copy OPML file to any place on SD card
2. Open Add Podcast - OPML Import - From local filesystem - Choose the file - Press OK

title: OPML Import is not working
body:
---

When trying to import subscriptions from OPML file, nothing happens.
Rotating progress bar appears for a short amount of time and no subscriptions are added.
The functionality works well on 1.5.2.0 version with all else constant: same file, same location, same Wi-Fi connection.

---

**App version:** 1.6.1.0 and 1.6.1.2

**Android version**: 2.3.4

**Device model**: LG P690

**Environment**: Rooted device, No Google Play Services installed

**Expected behaviour**: All the chosen subscription are added to the podcast list

**Current behaviour**: None of the chosen subscription are added to the podcast list

**First occured**: Version 1.6.1.0

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Copy OPML file to File system root
2. Open Add Podcast - OPML Import - From local filesystem - Choose file - Press OK

title: Warn users when adding MP4/OGG feed
body:
[following https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/2101#issuecomment-244724762]

Quite often a reported 'bug' concerns an MP4 or OGG feed, while these formats are not well-supported by Android natively. To prevent a portion of these errors, it might be good to warn users when they try to add an OGG or MP4 feed.

When adding a feed by tapping on "Subscribe", it could check the filetype of the latest episode, and display a warning dialog with the text "You have subscribed to an OGG or MP4 feed. Android's support for these filetypes is sub-optimal. We suggest subscribing to an MP3 feed, if available." The dialog should also contain a don't-show-this-again-checkbox, I guess.

title: Edit feed URLs
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2 (from Google Play

**Android version**: 7 (Android N)

**Device model**: Nexus 5x

**Expected behaviour**: Being able to edit the feed URL of an existing subscription

**Current behaviour**: Currently it is only possible to copy the feed URL to the clipboard.

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Subscribe to a feed
2. Go to the feed
3. Tap on the (i)  (information) - there are details like URL - but no way for editing it
## Workaround

Delete existing subscription and re-subscribe.

Big disadvantage: all downloaded files are deleted and all the status flags are lost (e.g. which episodes were already downloaded and played).
## Possible Implementation

(i.e. the how): Just make the URL label editable in the subscription information dialog (which is reachable via the (i) icon, from the subscription tab).

This dialog already contains some editable fields like password/username or auto-delete-episodes.

Alternative: add an edit button right beside the existing copy-button.
## Motivation

From time to time some of my subscriptions has feed URL issues, e.g. the author changed the URL and screwed up setting up the redirection. In those cases I would like to just copy and paste the new URL into a feed configuration dialog to update just the URL.

BTW, from a UI design perspective, I find the (i) (information icon) isn't very intuitive. Before accidentally hitting it I searched multiple times in the preferences menu of that tab for a settings item. IMHO it would also be an improvement to add a menu entry to the settings menu (which already has the entries 'refresh menu', 'Flattr this', ..., 'Remove Podcast').

title: CircleCI builds fail intermittently
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Quite a few pull requests fail: I believe the build failures are specific to CircleCI, rather than the files changed. What could be done about it? Thanks.

The affected pull requests include (at least):
#2119, #2117, #2130, #2096 ...

CircleCI errors:

> Your build has exceeded the memory limit of 4G on 1 container. The results of this build are likely invalid. We have taken a snapshot of the memory usage at the time, which you can find in a build artifact named `memory-usage.txt`. The RSS column in this file shows the amount of memory used by each process, measured in kilobytes.

title: Added preference settings to customize fastforward and rewind delta.
body:
Added preference settings to customize fastforward and rewind delta. Closes #2129. 
Minor: Fixes title case in preference setting titles 
Minor: Fixes typo in naming of UserPreferences.getFastFowardSecs to UserPreferences.getFastForwardSecs.

title: [Proposed Enhancement] Preference settings to customize fastforward and rewind delta
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
This enhancement adds two preference settings to the application preferences to control the delta when clicking fast forward of rewind.

Currently these values can be changed by long pressing on the fast forward/rewind button, but this is somewhat hard to discover.  This enhancement adds these preferences to the "Settings" view.

title: Show downloaded episodes in subscription counter
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body: See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/antennapod/oIucXvdjruE

title: Auto-download loop on download error
body:
---

A radio show I listen updates the podcast rss before the airing adding an item with info about the upcoming episode but, obviously, without an url of the show.

the link, enclosure, guid tags looks like this:

```
<item>
...
  <link/>
  <enclosure length="10000" type="audio/mpeg" url=""/>
  <guid/>
</item>
```

after the show airs they update the podcast rss and the tags became like this:

```
<item>
...
  <link>http://audio.radio24.ilsole24ore.com/radio24_audio/2016/160917-conti-belva-s.mp3</link>
  <enclosure length="10000" type="audio/mpeg" url="http://audio.radio24.ilsole24ore.com/radio24_audio/2016/160917-conti-belva-s.mp3"/>
  <guid>http://audio.radio24.ilsole24ore.com/radio24_audio/2016/160917-conti-belva-s.mp3</guid>
</item>
```

I have auto-donwload active and when antennapod updates this podcast it tries to download a file that doesn'e exist and it loop. I have to manually disable autodownoad for that episode in order to stop from keeping popping-up error messages.

The podcast is this: http://www.radio24.ilsole24ore.com/podcast/conti-belva.xml
the show airs saturdays at 10am gmt+2 and the rss is updated usually friday evening without url. It then gets updated again when the show finishes at about 1pm gmt+2.

Here is the rss before and after: [gist](https://gist.github.com/nixxo/84cbcd12a3bc8abe1a12acb5eecf7ab6)

Hope you can fix it.

Cheers, nixxo

---

**App version:** 1.6.1.2 (from Google Play)

**Android version**: 4.4.4 [Paranoid android custom rom for sm-g350]

**Devide model**: sm-g350

**Expected behaviour**: Don't loop after the first error

**Current behaviour**: The apps keeps trying downloading and keeps displaying errors

title: HTML not rendered
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
With RSS the feed description tag only allows plain text, but the equivalent in Atom is [subtitle](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4287#section-4.2.12) and that does allow HTML.

In AntennaPod it gets [parsed](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/syndication/namespace/atom/NSAtom.java#L188) correctly, but when being viewed on either [FeedInfo](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/activity/FeedInfoActivity.java#L156) or [OnlineFeedView](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/activity/OnlineFeedViewActivity.java#L415) activities it is just displayed in a textview.

The best solution would be to render it in both places, I tried to do that but I don't understand the system in AntennaPod for displaying shownotes. If I could have, I would have done another pull request. The easier but more disappointing thing to do would be to trim the HTML like you do in the OnlineFeedViewActivity for shownotes.

title: Support Atom's summary tag
body: Content is still preferred and used as default if both are present. But if it isn't it will use summary, usually a vague few sentences instead of show notes.

title: Intermittent crashes near the start / end of episodes, during MediaSessionCompat.setMetadata()
body:
---

**Workaround**  (Sep 29 2016):
If your device is entry level or has little memory, try disabling lockscreen background in the settings. Disabling lockscreen background probably would alleviate most of the problems.

---

**Problem Summary**:
- When playing to near the end of episodes (or about to start the next one), Antennapod on my phone crashes intermittently but often enough (ballpark about 10% of time). 
- logcat indicated indicated OutOfMemory error (need to allocate 7.5Mb),  but I believed the device still enough of memory at that point (device had at least 30Mb free memory, though I understand it does not necessarily mean they are available to antennapod).
- The problem probably occurred around switching cover art `OutOfMemoryError` stacktrace shows it is triggered by `Bitmap.nativeCopy()` < ... ... < `MediaSessionCompat.setMetadata()` < `antennapod...PlaybackService$$Lambda$2.run()` 
- It happened irrespective of whether phone screen is on: in other words, if the error was indeed triggered by switching covert art, the cover art was not needed nor in display at all (from end user perspective) as the screen was off.

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks!

---

**App version:** 1.6.1.2 from Play (and later a Custom Release Build based on 1.6.1.2 with PR #2117)

**Android version**: 4.1.2

**Devide model**: Samsung Galaxy Exhibit T-599H

**First occured**: a few weeks ago when I first used AntennaPod (1.6.1.2)

title: gpodder force full sync
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Sometime happens that one device have a delayed upload of episode action, but the others is already synced, then will be this event never synced, except i delete all date of the app and start from Scratch

it is like the http://gpoddernet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/reference/events.html#get-episode-actions "since" parameter is set to a newer timestamp so older event from a delayed upload will be ignored.

possible solution in gpodder menu additional to the sync now button, a new one for full sync (ignoring the since parameter) or maybe as long press...

**App version:** 1.6.1.2

**Android version**: 6 .01 /6 .0.1cm13 ZNH5YA

**Devide model**:nexus 9 /one plus one

```
```

title: FR: Support filtering in Episodes screen all tab
body:
Use case: 
- I'd like to manually download some (older) podcast episodes, with no specific podcast in mind.
- So I go to Episodes screen > All tab, I found the episodes across all podcasts
- Pain point: the list is interspersed with all the downloaded episodes (grayed out), making it harder to browse for episodes. 

Note: this request sounds similar to #2118, but #2118 addresses the issue on podcast screen, while this feature request is for Episodes screen (across all podcasts)

---

Proposal:
- Add a filtering button. From user's perspective, it works the same way as the "3 dashes" filter button, allowing users to filter (and show) only not downloaded episodes.
- the UI will indicate the list is filtered: maybe adding circle-i icon to the tab title (the circle-i icon is from podcast screen). 
- Other options from podcast screen (played, not queued, etc.) can carry over for consistency sake. They may not make much sense in episodes screen, but might still fulfill some other use cases.

Thoughts?

title: Fix build on windows with gradle-retrolambda plugin upgrade
body:
On windows platform task :core:compileRetrolambdaPlayDebug often fails, generating error 

```
 CreateProcess error=206, The filename or extension is too long
```
- See issue in the underlying retrolambda plugin: 
  evant/gradle-retrolambda#206

title: filtering episodes
body:
Hi! I love antennapod and am very grateful for the open source app! I have just recently started using it (version 1.6.1.2 on Android 5.1.1) and here are two issues I can't figure out:
1. Basically, sometimes I need to filter episodes oldest to newest first - for listening to history podcasts for example. By accessing the "3 sprockets" settings button, episodes in a subscribed podcast can easily be filtered  in any possible way but when I return to the podcast page that certain filter gets lost. Using the "3 dashes" filter gives much fewer options. Can't figure this one out...
2. So I proceed to scroll way down to the bottom (since the only way they seem to be sorted is newest at the top, oldest at the bottom) and click on the oldest episode, say "episode 1". When that one finishes, sometimes it will continue playing "episode 2" then "episode 3" etc. which, ok, I can live with. But sometimes it'll happily jump to "episode 8" next, skipping a few in between and so on... In other words, it's not consistent and I can't predict if it'll play the right thing or not.

I hope it isn't confusing.
I appreciate any help and thank you very much!

title: Issue #2105 : support optional rewind in lockscreen
body:
It addresses #2105 . Behavior:
- if the user selects Rewind in Lockscreen Buttons settings, then the user can rewind in lockscreen 
- the button shown on lockscreen is previous button (Android's own limitation).

Discussion:
- overloading previous button as rewind should not confuse the user: AntennaPood does not support previous. The Lockscreen Buttons settings only provide rewind (no  previous). 
- the change (in `MediaSessionCompat` object) is consistent with the existing logic in the associated  `sessionCallback` object in [`onSkipToPrevious()`](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/1.6.1.2/core/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/core/service/playback/PlaybackService.java#L1529) method's implementation is actually rewind.
- the fix in PR #2109 addresses hardware previous button. It is still consistent from user's perspective

Open:
- I am not entirely sure the behavior in Android 5+ devices.

Thanks.

title: Unplayed episodes appear in "Recently played" list
body:
If I listen to an episode and it ends, AntennaPod stops playing. Looking at the "Recently played" list, there is the episode that just ended, PLUS the episode that was below it in the queue, even though that one was obviously not played.

**Expected behavior:** Just add episodes that have actually been started (by manually tapping the play icon or by the auto-play feature)

**Use-case:** I delete played episodes after some time (when I'm sure I don't need them anymore). When doing this, I just scroll through the "Recently played" list. It is quite confusing that nearly every second episode appearing there has never been played.

title: An option to disable image cache

body: How: just add "0Mb" or "Disable" option before the 20Mb one and show images only when connection is available without storing them on the disk.

title: Allow choosing between getDuration and getPlayedDuration
body: This new setting makes it easier to keep statistics even when switching podcast clients (by marking as played). It also respects podcasts you listened to before getPlayedDuration was introduced. Related discussion: http://www.github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/pull/1841

title: Playback event log
body:
Hello,

it would be great if application logged playback events of episodes somewhere (next to the episode/globally or both). The entries could be like:
- Episode X: started playing at position [mm:ss]  on [datetime 1] by [UI/headphones/bluetooth]
- Episode X: paused playing at [mm:ss] on [datetime 2] by [UI/headphones/bluetooth/sleep timer]
- Episode X: resumed playing at [mm:ss] on [datetime 3] by [UI/headphones/bluetooth]
  ....

Clicking (or long clicking maybe to avoid misclicks) on the entry would start playback at the specified position.

Not sure if this log should include rewinds/fast forwards in order to avoid cluttering the log. Probably not worth it in the first incarnation of the feature. Other improvements could include commenting on the entries later or e.g. capturing GPS location of the event.

Why would it be VERY useful for me? Well, sometimes I resume playback (without looking at the position first) and get distracted by something (but don't stop playback). Or better yet, I simply fall asleep sometimes even having no idea that I fell asleep :). So next time I would rather go back to the position where I started and figure out what I missed from there rather than try to figure out the same thing from the position I finally stopped the playback at (which is typically the end of the episode or another episode anyway, so this method is kind of useless :-) )

Think about it, this could also serve as a poorman's bookmarking in some sense ( https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/1946 ). You could "artificially" pause/resume playback (even better, do it via headphones) to get the log entry when you want to "bookmark". If you do not do this frequently, at least for me it is much easier to remember the datetime (that is a global "parameter" which you can approximate quite efficiently) rather than playback position which I have no idea about.

Thank you for considering. This would be a KILLER feature for me. Being a java programmer I was thinking about implementing this myself but I have zero Android experience and not much free time at the moment. So it would take quite a long for me.

Thank you making a great open source podcast app!

title: Set current position to the begining on 'Previous' button
body: If the user enables 'shouldHardwareButtonSkip' is likely there exist separate hardware buttons for 'Next' and 'Forward' functions. In this case, it's likely there exist also separate 'Previous' and 'Rewind' hardware buttons (as in my car stereo connected by bluetooth).  If that is the case, it is useless both buttons have the same function, it is more intuitive that the 'Previous' button restart the current track from its beginning as most players do. This patch does that.

title: Frequently running out of cache
body:
I subscribe to a daily podcast that has each episode of about 140 MB. I had previously requested to have an option to keep only one episode as minimum but it was rejected and the minimum number of episodes to keep is 5. I have enabled the option to delete an episode when it has finished but quite often I don't have the time to watch the podcast on a daily basis. Consequently I see the exclamation mark next to Download every few days and the automatic download stops. I have to manually delete the last 3-4 episodes before the automatic download process restores. The only "cache" option i see in settings is for image setting which I have set to max, 500 MB.
Can you please propose a solution to the frequent overloading of the cache? Thank you for a great app!

title: Option to disable auto download on specific podcast
label: [Label(name="invalid")]
body:
This feature request is somewhat related to #1077 (Option to auto download oldest episode first). The use case is this:
- A podcast that is "low-priority" that I do not want to download it until I have time to listen.
- Furthermore, the podcast is serial in nature, so it does not make much sense to listen to the latest episode without first catching up on the older ones.

If I can disable auto download on the specific podcast, I can then go to podcast screen and download specific episodes (the oldest unplayed ones) when I have time to listen.

Thoughts?

---

How to implement:
- On the podcast screen, add there is an additional menu item for settings (for the podcast)
- a new settings "pop-in" screen can allow the users to disable auto download.

title: Feature Request: Support for Chapter-Images
body:
### What is a chapter image?

Chapter-Images are basically the same like a Chapter-Mark but have an image attached which could/should be displayed on the device when the related chapter is reached during playing the podcast. 
### Only few podcasts make use of chapters/images. Why should it get implemented?

In general only a few Podcatchers support Chapter-Marks and even less support Chapters-Images. An argument often stated is that not many Podcasts make use of these features but in my eyes this is a chicken-egg-question. I might be wrong but I think most of the time the services should offer a technology first so that users can make use of it.
### Do chapter-images make sense for an audio-only podcast?!

It's right, that he user would have to look at the smartphone/screen to see the image which makes no sense at first since we're talking about audio-only podcasts. But in fact, it's a wonderful feature.

For example here we've a German Podcast where Photographers talk intensively about 5 pictures over the course of a podcast episode (which goes ~2h). It's not mainly about the photo itself but more about the circumstances and situation where the photographer took the picture - still, it's just nice to see the photo they're talking about. Therefore, while listening, some times you can hear a "camera trigger"-sound which is placed at the position in the podcast where a picture got visible on your device. You don't have to, but now you can have a short look at the screen to see exactly what they're talking about (below you can find a link to this podcast).

http://bildsprache-podcast.de/bsp013-professor-rolf-nobel

I think this is a perfect sweet-spot between audio and video. The only alternative for showing a picture would be to 
- provide a video podcast (which would create a huge overhead for just showing off 5 pictures)
- force the listener to go to a website to look at the picture
- not to do a podcast like this - which would be a shame, because the podcast is awesome. :)

My personal project is a Game Development Podcast - sometimes the topics may be complicated. We'll try to describe them as well as possible with our voices but I'll include pictures when it might help for a better understanding.
### How have others implemented chapter-images?

The pictures would need to be visible within the chapter-mark-list. Here you can see an example of the Podlove WebPlayer on my website (https://gamedevpodcast.de/00/) and how iTunes does it:

https://media.gamedevpodcast.de/tutorial_chapterimages_01.png

You can see the image directly in the list (which in this case is a cat as an example-image). 
Imagine how useful this could be to find the chapter you're looking for - if you know they talked about "PacMan" or "C++" and the image in this list shows this as a graphic/logo, you don't even have to read through all chapter-marks.

**Important**: As soon as the chapter with the image is reached, a bigger version is displayed. In case of the Standard iOS Podcast App it looks like below: 

https://media.gamedevpodcast.de/tutorial_chapterimages_02.png

Here you can find a list of other programs which support chapter images at least in M4A:

http://gamedevpodcast.de/tipps/#podcatcher

By the way: It's super interesting that not only M4A but also MP3 supports chapters as well as chapter-images. I'm sorry for my long explanation but thank you soo much for taking the time!

Thanks for reading this long text and have a nice day!
Simon

title: Antennapod dies when trying to play an episode of "Logbuch:Netzpolitik"
label: [Label(name="wontfix")]
body:
Every Episode from Logbuch:Netzpolitik lets AntannoPod crash. I added the podcast via the Itunes search but I can confirm the behaviour when getting it via Gpodder. Both playing a downloaded episode and the streaming option let AntennaPod die on me. I tried it out with the latest 3 episodes, I guess it's the same for all of them.

**App version:** 1.6.1.2 (F-Droid)

**Android version**: 5.1.1 (Cyanogenmod: 12.1-20160314-NIGHTLY-osprey)

**Devide model**: Motorola Moto G3

title: Large MediaStyle notification (with large album on left) is not triggered
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Using Android 6.0 here.

I noticed that the MediaStyle notification is not actually triggered. This has two effects on the user experience:
1. The large album art in notifications, [which looks like this](http://i.stack.imgur.com/a7XDm.png), is not triggered.
2. The podcast's album art doesn't become my wallpaper when I'm listening to a podcast.

I found the reason that this was not triggering: MediaStyle notification only supports up to 3 actions in standard-size view aka `contentView` (and up to 5 in `bigContentView`). (See [MediaStyle documentation](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v7/app/NotificationCompat.MediaStyle.html).) The app is currently attempting to display 4 actions in `contentView`: rewind, pause, fast-forward, and skip.

I verified, by testing, that reducing the number of actions to 3 does indeed trigger both large album art and album art as wallpaper.

Should we change the behavior of the app so that MediaStyle is triggered properly? If so, we should reduce the number of action buttons. Which action buttons should we remove?

title: FR: Setting for changing the sorting for the side panel listing
label: [Label(name="invalid")]
body:
Hi

It looks like the side panel subscription listing is sorted based on the number of episodes and there is no way to change that behavior. It would be greta if we could set things based on alphabetical order,  connection problems etc.

I am using the F-droid version.
thanks

title: Swipe to remove "New" label in Feed view
body:
Since I stopped falsely marking episodes as played and removed the 'New' label instead to indicate I'm not interested in a particular episode I have to do this 'management' via de (New) Episodes view.

Sometimes, however, I would like to 'de-new' multiple episodes from a feed (because they're old or there's no time to catch up and that particular feed is of least interest to me).
I would therefore like to propose 'Swipe to remove new label in feed view' (disabled for a particular episode if it already doesn't have the new label anymore).

title: Add "New plus queued" to counter options
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I would like to sort my feeds according to the amount of episodes I (possibly) want to listen to.

Before I marked episodes I don't want to listen to (falsely) as 'Played'. Now I either add an item to the queue or swipe it away from the 'new' list (depending on whether I'm interested or not).

To get a correct feel of which feeds have the highest amount of episodes I (might) want to listen to, it would be nice to be able to sort feeds according to "New plus queued episodes".

title: fix cover fragment onMediaChanged
body:
I believe this issue hasn't been reported, but this is the way to reproduce it:
while using `MediaPlayerInfoActivity`, for instance while playing an audio episode, if the episode changes (either it ends or we skip) the next episode shows up. However, if go all the way to the chapters page and back to the cover page, the cover of the previous episode will show instead.
Here's my theory: 2 pages away the fragment gets destroyed, but when it is created again, it fetches the media that was passed to it as an argument on its instantiation, which won't be the same as the current media.

title: Prevent authentication header to be set for s3 presigned-urls
body:
This pull-request adds a check for Amazon AWS S3 pre-signed urls so that authentication headers are not set. This is because S3 does not allow both an authentication header and a pre-signed url at the same time ([Amazon documentation](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/RESTAuthentication.html)).

This will resolve the issue discussed in [Google Groups](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/antennapod/C89LMPtUqpg).

title: Can't download more than one episode at a time
body:
**App version:** 1.6.1.2(from Google Play)

**Android version**: 7.0

**Devide model**: Nexus 6P

**Expected behaviour**: Trying to download a whole podcast results in a download que that finishes at some point. Alternatively, the download hickups but restarts itself. 

**Current behaviour**: Trying to download more than 1 episode at once, or having a download que causes the whole download process to crash, making me have to restart the download manually. I'm not sure at what point this usually happens exactly, but I think it's at about when the first one finishes. 

Checked that this is for all podcasts that I have. 

_Error message_: Unknown Host: Unable to resolve host "Different for each podcast": No address associated with host name. 

This error did not happen to me using Pocket Casts, trying the same podcasts

**First occured**: Version 1.6.1.2 (just downloaded the app)

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Open "apply actions" for a podcast
2. Try to download more than 1 episode simultaneously or put more than one episode into the download que. 
3. Wait for one of the episodes to finish downloading

title: optionally enable the sleep timer always when playing episodes
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Feature request:
I think it might be useful for some people (including me) to have a setting for a sleep timer which is active always when you start playback of an episode because at least I often forget to enable a sleep timer in the evening and when I wake up in the morning my half queue has been played. This could be set in the global settings. I don't think it would be too annoying to press play again when I want to listen for a longer time, for example in a train.

title: Add warning before streaming
label: [Label(name="wontfix")]
body:
Streaming causes the playback buttons, including the notification player, to act sporadically and unreliably when the playback speed isn't 1x. 

The conclusion I drew from this is that the app itself must be buggy, so for a while I switched. I lated realized that **other podcast apps do not even allow** the user to have playback control during streaming, probably for this very reason. 

I understand that fixing the streaming issue might not be a priority, but adding this warning, _at least the first time_ the user attempts this, will probably get more users to stick with the app instead of concluding it must be all around buggy.

title: Improve MRSS support
body:
Add support for one mrss thumbnail, and description. Closes https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/1699

If an enclosure (content) is marked as default it can override an actual enclosure. For feeds that use mrss' content, they usually have the default one also be the enclosure, but if they don't this will still honor the default attribute.

An enhancement request after reading #2080: now the refresh spinner (animation) in the episodes app bar restarts upon every feed that is being updated, meaning that it flashes every three seconds or so.

Would be nice if it would keep running continuously until all feeds have been updated.

title: Update animation stops before update is finished
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
(google play store, cyanogenmod nightly)

Just a small issue:
- Go the "Episodes"
- Click the "Update" icon in the top right corner
- It starts spinning and in the notification area an update icon appears

title: Need a way to see only media content of a podcast
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:

title: hide episode button - 'one click hide'
body:
### Proposal

It would be neat to have a _hide episode_ button on **each** episode entry in the episode list of a podcast to be able to hide an episode from the list **with just one click/tap**.
### Justification

Let's assume that there are many podcasts that have many episodes of which quite a few are not interesting to the listener (which is true for me). I don't think it's a good idea and it's also not efficient to keep these uninteresting episodes in the list ... adding up with time. That's why a button to hide an episode **with just one click** would be nice. If there's many episodes to hide, I don't want to have to long press for the context menu and then do another click/tap.

AFAIK currently one can only long press on an episode (for the context menu) to mark it as played or use the advanced menu (to perform actions on multiple episodes), but that still keeps it in the list. Also misusing the _play status_ to hide non interesting episodes would make things more confusing since interesting episodes would also get the _played_ status.
### Implementation

As it currently looks the download button uses the whole height of an episode entry. I think this space would suffice for two buttons:_download_ and _hide_ stacked.

Of course the proposed feature would require an additional status of an episode: _hidden_
But it shouldn't be too difficult to implement, since statuses like _played_, _downloaded_ already exist.

title: Use MIME types in OPML import intent filter (fixes #1758)
body:
Using an intent filter based on file extensions is unreliable: for example, K-9 Mail sends out intents with URI's like `content://com.fsck.k9.debug.attachmentprovider/75a212fa-2aa8-473c-ad4d-e4e86eff0bf7/5` when opening attachments, meaning any `intent-filter` relying on catching `*.opml` files will fail; also, extra dots in a file's path will break wildcard characters in `android:pathPattern`.

Using MIME types is currently the best option available. OPML files are often detected as `application/octet-stream` (a catch-all for unknown types) meaning the intent filter will catch files such as `.nomedia` etc., but I think that the amount of such files a user will come across is small enough that it won't really matter.

Fixes #1758

title: fix horizontal layout (MediaRouteControllerDialog)
body:
This was really a pain. Horizontal LinearLayout's behavior is to first resolve the widths of its children and only then figure out any height restrictions. For a child view that imposes a certain aspect ratio, this means that once the height changes, its width is also going to change, but at that point the width is already fixed for all the other children, and LinearLayout doesn't ask them to update their dimensions.
Solution: override onMeasure on the LinearLayout to have a first pass through its children heights.

Hi,
I've tried many things to see why I can't download some episodes from this podcast before posting this issue to make it more constructive, but I'm not sure which url uses AntennaPod to download them, so I'm afraid I can't help too much. Thanks for your help.

I think the best way of doing this is for the played episodes to be grayed out, just like they are when looking at the podcast feed list. I would appreciate the chance to work on this feature.

When choosing which episode to listen to, I primarily choose episodes to listen to from the Completed Downloads list. This allows me to access all the episodes I have currently downloaded, from various podcasts, all on one screen. I also use this screen to delete episodes I have already listened to.
