<mvdan> we just can't find some of those deps
<mvdan> sure, you can quote me. but of course I could be wrong.
<me> no one's ever wrong on the internet
<mvdan> i'd rather be wrong than sorry, hah

title: Feature request: optionally mark episodes as unread when adding a new feed
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I understand the rationale for not offering the ability to mark episodes as unread (although I don't agree with it...). But I don't think this rationale applies when you've added a new feed - in some cases, you'd probably need to start from episode 1 but you wouldn't necessarily want top add 200+ episodes to the queue.

For example, many educational podcasts will need to be listened to in order, as later episodes will use concepts introduced earlier ones. In my case, I have a beginners Spanish podcast that I've started listening to with a few hundred episodes already recorded and tracking where I'm up to is already a bit of a pain.

With this in mind, could we have an option when adding the feed to mark the entire feed unread?

title: Bug: reading autostart on unlocking
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
When the headphone are disconnected, AP stops playing. That's fine.
However, as one has to unlock the phone to do anything with it, then AP restarts playing.
This is a recent behavior, and should not happen, at least for this use case:
using the headphone removal to stop playing, then moving on to something else.
If it is not a bug but a recent feature, could it be optionnal? Thanks.

title: Feature Request: allow installing/moving application to SD card
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I've got a very memory-challenged phone, and am always trying to skim a few MB on the internal memory to be able to install new apps, but unfortunately AntennaPod can't be moved to the SD card.

I believe this is done adding [android:installLocation](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/data/install-location.html) to the manifest file. I'd suggest using "preferExternal", although "auto" (install by default on internal memory, on external if internal is already full)

title: Feature Request: Per-feed option to not add episodes to new list
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I am subscribed to 2 high-frequency podcasts (daily 07:00 and 19:00 radio news), which I only infrequently listen to: maybe once a week I'll manually download the latest episode.
But those 2 feeds show up with 2 new episodes per day in the list of recent episodes, which to me only represent noise.

I would appreciate a way to "hide" the episodes from these feeds in the list of new episodes. This would be a per-feed option, "do not show new episodes in list". With such a feature, i could go to the Feed and download the latest episode, only when I want to listen to an episode. The rest of the time, those episodes don't fill up the newest episodes, and that list has more meaningful items in it ;)

title: Back 30 seconds does not work if less than 30 seconds have been played
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
When playing an episode, pressing the << button goes back 30 seconds. If you were less than 30 seconds into an episode, that button press doesn't do anything. I would have expected the episode to go back to 0.

(I believe the same might be happening with the >> button if you're less than 30 seconds away from the end of the episode, but I can't test/confirm right now)

title: Regression in 0.9.7.5: "Settings" menu does not update itself for changes in submenus.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Setting the number in "Episode cache" does not update until Setting menu gets closed and opened again.
In 0.9.7.4 it worked as expected.

Similar behaviour can be observed also within "Automatic download":  Setting the tick at "Automatic download" does not enable "Enable Wi-Fi filter".  To get "Enable Wi-Fi filter accessible you need to exit from the "Settings" menu completely and choose "Settings/Automatic download" again.

title: Most Recent Episode incorrect following podcast with no episodes
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
v0.9.7.5
In the podcast list screen, when there is a podcast with no episodes, it is displayed as "Most Recent Episode" of the next podcast in the list.
The subsequent "Most Recent Episode" timestamps are are also incorrect, each being shuffled up i.e. podcast number 3 has the timestamp from podcast 4, podcast 4 has the timestamp from podcast 5 and so on.

Device:
Samsung Galaxy Ace 2 GT-I18160 Android 4.1.2

title: Most bitmaps/icons not showing
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Recently icons stopped loading, both in podcast and episodes tab.

I get this in logcat:
`09-17 10:02:31.398 W/BitmapDecodeWorkerTask( 7056): Could not load bitmap. Using default image.
09-17 10:02:31.452 W/BitmapDecodeWorkerTask( 7056): Could not load bitmap. Using default image.
09-17 10:02:31.476 W/BitmapDecodeWorkerTask( 7056): Could not load bitmap. Using default image.`

Not sure since when this is happening.

title: Return when playing external media
body:
Actually this is only about commit d72c2e9, not sure where I can change the merge request target from danieloeh:master to danieloeh:develop... 

I made the experience with both filemanagers I use (OI FileManager and the cyanogenmod filemanager app), that AntennaPod (and other apps) don't disconnect and return to the filemanager.

What I mean is this: open mp3 file in the filemanager -> launches AudioPlayerActivity, switch back to homescreen (music is playing in the background), launch filemanager -> I land in the AudioPlayerActivity, while for me the expected behaviour upon launching the filemanager would be to end up in the filemanager activity.

This change remedies the issue. I am not sure if there might be any unintended side-effects, I haven't observed any upon testing though.

title: Streaming to extern player
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body: i would love to see a ability to stream a episode to a extern player. like bubbleupnp or the yatse xbmc remote. its something i use alot to play podcasts on my xmbc machine. i dont know how difficult this is... but it would be a nice feature.

title: Missing i18n for ProgressDialog of "Remove Feed" action
Menu disappeared from action bar
body:
Hey, 

On my device (Asus PadFone 2, Android 4.1) the menu button has  disappeared  (like the play button in issue #273) from the podcast description activity so simply I can not play anything :-(

It happened after I upgraded to the last version (v0.9.7.5)

Thanks,

Yoni

title: Google TV AnntenaPod issue - Pause key on the Google TV remote does not pause playback
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
In Google TV 3.2 Logitech Revue, pressing the pause button on the device's remote does not pause the video.  When the pause button is pressed on the device's remote, the video appears to re-buffer and then continues to play.  

(Pressing skip forward and skip back buttons on the remote do work properly however :D )

Pressing pause via the app's UI with a mouse press does properly pause the video's playback.

AntennaPod 0.9.7.5

title: Google TV AntennaPod issue - Video no longer plays in full screen
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
In Google TV 3.2 Logitech Revue on a 1080p TV, using AntennaPod 16:9 video has a significant black border on the bottom, left and right edges.  The previous version properly scaled the video to full screen without any borders.

I don't know if its not scaling the 16:9 720p source video is not scaling enough.  I think it might be scaling it but just not to maximum resolution of the display.

AntennaPod 0.9.7.5

title: Bug: Google TV AntennaPod crashes when settings is selected
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Running Google TV 3.2 Logitech Revue, app crashes when settings menu is selected.

AntennaPod 0.9.7.5

title: Playback button disappeared from action bar
body:
In the episode preview, there used to be a playback button (as seen in this old screenshot here: http://blog.znn.info/antennapod/20121116_224017/). Instead, there is now a playback item in the context menu as shown in the attached screenshot.

Can we please have the button back?

title: gradle doesn't seem to believe there is an assembleDebug
label: [Label(name="project issue")]
body:
I'm trying to build AntennaPod to fix an issue, since it's such a great project and I want to contribute back. I'm having an issue compiling; I'm on Debian, and installed gradle by unzipping the gradle ZIP distribution from its website. I unzipped it into ~/gradle-1.7/ and got this error: 
androider@pathi:~/AntennaPod$ ~/gradle-1.7/bin/gradle assembleDebug

FAILURE: Could not determine which tasks to execute.

* What went wrong:
Task 'assembleDebug' not found in root project 'antennapod'.

* Try:
Run gradle tasks to get a list of available tasks.

BUILD FAILED

Total time: 3.84 secs
I'm hoping to do the compile with gradle rather than eclipse, and it seems to me that this should work according to https://github.com/danieloeh/AntennaPod/wiki/Building-AntennaPod#building-on-the-command-line-with-gradle . If the issue is a documentation error, and you can describe what I need to do here, I am willing to fix the docs too if I can reproduce that the solution works for me, too. Let me know. Thanks!

title: Sort mecanism broken
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Hello,

Since yesterday, I can not sort episodes anymore.
It used to work fine.
Now, when trying to move an episode up or down: after following my finger, when I drop it where I wan it, the complete list flickers, then it goes back to its initial position.
I am using AntennaPod 0.9.7.4 on Android 4.1.2 since a few months.

What can I do, except uninstall / reinstall (and lose all my history) ?
Could it be a missing right on a file somewhere, lost for an unknown reason?
Thanks for your help.

title: Feature Request: Read/Unread marker
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body: A cool feature would be the ability to mark episodes as played in the podcast's list of episodes. You could turn the title text grey to signify that the episode has been listened to. I follow a lot of podcasts and it would be nice to see which I've finished listening to and which ones I haven't. I know that this functionality is sort of provided by having a queue, but just a suggestion. I used to use a Zune for podcasts and really liked how it managed them.

title: Download Error on Files with a Colon (":")
body:
Each time AntennaPod is trying to download an episode containing a colon ":" in the filename it will fail end result in the following Error:

IO Error: /storage/extSdCard/AntennaPod/media/DRadio Wissen - Medien/dradiowissen_ct-gespraech:_20130830_f0c443f5.mp3: open failed: EINVAL (Invalid argument)

As AntennaPod is going to try it again and again... this will result in a long list of errors in the Download Log.

title: Opus leads to silent failure
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
I just added this feed:

http://freakshow.fm/feed/opus/

it downloads fine, but trying to play crashes antennapod on my Galaxy Nexus. I guess a warning dialog/check for supported formats would be a good idea.

title: Updated so that the headings display properly
body:
Previously headings would just display with two *\* on either side of the heading.

The proper markdown is to use '-' underneath the heading.

title: Iframes are open separately
label: [Label(name="bug"), Label(name="needs info")]
body:
Feed Items which contain an Iframe are open in an external browser. They should probably be opened inline.

The thing is that shouldOverrideUrlLoading() is called for iframes while loading the page, and not only when user clicks on a link.

I am not sure about the workaround, but i think we should use a condition in handling of  shouldOverrideUrlLoading():
- While page is loading assume url is an iframe and load internally (return false).
- After page finished loading use current behaviour, load externally (do the intent and return true).

title: Crash on certain urls
body:
This feed causes a crash when I try to open the chapter about BASIC language:
http://retroactivo.es/feed/

Logcat says:
android.content.ActivityNotFoundException: No Activity found to handle Intent { act=android.intent.action.VIEW dat=//storify.com/retroactivos/retroactivo-28-basic-el-lenguaje-de-programacion/embed }

And I can recognize a special URL in an IFRAME like:
<iframe src="//storify.com/retroactivos/retroactivo-28-basic-el-lenguaje-de-programacion/embed">

It is not malformed, despite there is no "http" at the begining (either http or https should be used according to the context).
A check should be performed at the begining of this method ItemDescriptionFragment.java:shouldOverrideUrlLoading(). Or the exception could be handled.

title: Force close when downloading an episode
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Whenever I ask AntennaPod to download an episode, it force closes. The crashes used to only happen when downloading everything in my queue, but now it crashes even when I request an individual episode to be downloaded. If I increase the number of episodes allowed in my cache, I can then download specific episodes for a few days and then it starts force closing again.

I suspect this is caused by two inter-related issues.
- When the episode cache is full, it force closes instead of cancelling the download and providing some intelligent message to the user
- It appears not clean up download episodes after listening to them. I recently cleared dozens of old episodes out of my media folder that were not deleted when I completed listening to them. I suspect that some counter was not cleared when I deleted the files, so the application still thinks I'm at my limit of cached episodes.

AntennaPod 0.9.7.4
Nexus 4, Build JWR66V

title: coherent menu entries
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Currently, it's not possible to enter Settings, Downloads & Playback History from the player view, so one always has to click back to the podcast or episode list 1st.

Please make these menu entries accessible in any view.

Esp. the "Continuous playback" and "Headphones disconnect" settings would be nice to have as a toggle-option directly in the menu. Like Firefox on Android has a "Request Desktop site" checkbox :-)

title: FR: click on widget should load episode list if no media is playing
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Currently, when no podcast is playing, the widget shows a generic "No media playing" message. Clicking it, brings up the empty "player page".

If one wants to select a new episode to play, one has to click the app logo to get back to the podcast list and once more on "EPISODES".

Please make it possible to skip this procedure by making the widget load the episode list directly, when none is playing.

title: Export to OPML in a public directory
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body: I went to export to OPML in order to migrate from the fdroid version to the Play version and didn't pay attention to where it saved the file. When I went to reinstall, the file was gone, as it was cleared with the app uninstall. It would be wonderful if it could be stored in a public place so fat fingers can't so easily wipe the backup. Maybe just on the root of the SD card or in the Downloads folder.

title: Support paged feeds.
body:
Hi

It would be nice to support [paged feeds](http://podlove.org/paged-feeds/).

title: Move to top/bottom
body:
This changes adds the menu options 'Move to top' and 'Move to bottom' to items in the Episode queue.  This change enhances usability by making it easier to quickly change what you will (or won't) be listening to yet.

Let me know if any changes are needed.

title: Pause on interrupt
body:
This change lets the user choose to have audio paused during 'duckable' transient focus loss instead of lowering the volume.  The advantage is that (for things like navigation) you'll be able to hear the interrupting stream properly and not miss anything from the playback in AntennaPod.

Please let me know if I need to make any changes for this to be accepted.

title: added android-test as a dependency to resolve build problems
body: As develop stands now the maven build breaks because it doesn't know about android.test.  This fixes that by adding  android-test as a dependency.

title: added android-test as a dependency to resolve build problems
body: This resolves a build issue related to unit testing that was introduced recently.

title: Connection error when url starts with "feed://"
body:
When trying to add podcast feed from url.
Invokes error-popup: "An error has occurred: Connection error"

Solved by removing the "feed://" prefix, and only use the "feeds.feedburner.com/podcastname" part.

This could be solved by automatically removing the protocol prefix on error and retrying.

title: Flattr queue autoflattr
body:
This implements a queue of pending things to flattr (similar to #203 but implemented in a slightly different fashion) and adds support for automatic flattring of played episodes as requested in #87.

The workflow for the user is:
- if autoflattr is enabled, whenever 80% of an episode have been played it is added to the flattr queue (and a toast is displayed)
- manual flattring is done directly (flattring things in the queue along the way) if there is an internet connection. Otherwise the thing is added to the queue.
- when the feeds are updated, things in the queue are flattred (presumably there is an internet connection at that point), an android notification is displayed. Also at that point the flattr status of things is updated from the flattr API

Database changes:
- new column flattr_status for the feed and feeditem tables containing the timestamp when the thing was last flattrd. This value is updated when antennapod flattrs, as well as based on data from the flattr API whenever the feeds are refreshed. The latter may not be 100% reliable as the URL antennapod gets from the feed is not necessarily exactly the one recorded by flattr and returned by their API. I implemented some URI normalization that catches the corner cases I have encountered, there may be more. Also the flattr api does not return information on flattrability (i.e. things that were flattrd last month), so this is done in Antennapod.

I have considered implementing the flattr queue as a list of URLs to flattr as you suggested in #203, but I think it would be a lot more work (i.e. one would have to walk through the entire queue and the list of things that have been flattrd just in order to determine if an item is flattrable (and the corresponding menu item should be shown, as well as in order to avoid trying to flattr things multiple times), similarly to retrieve the feed titles of the things flattrd for showing in the notification). 
- new column played_duration for the feedmedia table containing for how long an episode has been played (this is the accumulated play time, _not_ the current play position in the episode)

title: AntennaPod forgets about already downloaded podcast episodes
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
AntennaPod "forgets" the already downloaded files within a very short time no matter if the episodes are downloaded manually or by the automatic download function (which is working for me btw).

What happens:
Download progress is looking good. After successful downloading there is an indication (arrow down) the files are stored locally and I can play them offline. Fine. But after closing and restarting the app most of the time (not always) the little indication is gone and AntennaPod is offering the download option again. That's wrong.
It's more annoying if one is using the automatic download function. The podcast episodes are downloaded over and over again until the sd-card is full(?). After 60 minutes I had a lot of files like xxxxx-1.mp3 xxxxxx-2.mp3 xxxxxx-3.mp3 and so on...

What am I using:
AntennaPod 0.9.7.4 (from F-Droid repo)
Android 4.2.2
Cyanogenmod 10.1.2
Path to podcasts: /storage/sdcard0/Podcasts/...

Best regards,
AlfredSK

title: Deleted feed is recreated after update
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
After deleting a feed, I updated manually the feeds.
During the update stage the deleted feed was recreated.

I am using the variable speed test version.

title: Fixes issue #249 (Cannot use Kinivo BTC450 bluetooth car kit to play after pause).
body:
The problem was that audioManager.abandonAudioFocus() was being called
before remoteControlClient.setPlaybackState(). That seems to have
prevented the BTC450 from knowing that the audio was paused. As a
result, the BTC450 continued to send "pause" instead of "play" for
subsequent button presses. The fix just moves the call to
abandonAudioFocus() until after setPlaybackState() has been called.

title: Cannot use Kinivo BTC450 bluetooth car kit to play after pause
body: I can use the Kinivo BTC450 to pause, but when I then try to use it to continue playing, nothing happens. I have small patch to fix this issue. Pull request to follow shortly.

title: AP downloads episodes even if not enough space is on the device.
body:
AntennaPod downloads episodes even if not enough space is on the device. So it downloads a episode of 100MB and then says "oh sorry not enought space left on device".

That's not funny if you only have some 100MB or 1GB of full speed mobile internet and then the bandwith drops to unusable for AntennaPods download mechanism.

Why doesn't AP checks if enough space is left **before** downloading a whole episode? I know there are some cases where you don't know how big the file will be, but in most cases it not a problem.

title: FR: remember sleep timer setting
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body: IMHO, there is a high probability that people want to use the same sleep timer settings. Currently, it has to be set anew each time. Please make AntennaPod remember the set sleep time. Thanks and greetings!

title: Ask for volume controls to affect media volume.
body: By default the volume controls on Android control the ringer volume.  It's useful to be able to adjust the media playback volume before hitting play; this does that for each activity that can start playback.

title: Support for paged-feeds
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Support for paged-feeds (RFC 5005) would help a lot !

please see http://podlove.org/paged-feeds/

The podcast http://cre.fm/feed/m4a/ uses it for example.
Currently I can only see the first page, the last 30 episodes.

I dont find any other android app that supports it.

title: Enqueue of new episodes in waiting list
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
It seems that new podcast episodes which get enqueued in the waiting list are added on top of the list, where the next downloaded episodes are taken from.

Is that correct?

title: Automatic feed updates are slow when device is asleep
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
I noticed that automatic feed refreshes for the ~ 50 feeds I subscribed to can take up to around 20 minutes when the device is asleep, in contrast to less than a minute when the device is awake.

This is happening because AntennaPod fails to hold a WakeLock while it is refreshing feeds or downloading media files. As a consequence, after the `FeedUpdateReceiver`'s `onReceive()` method returns, the device will go back to sleep, although the actual downloads are still pending.

title: Pause playback
body: Thee playback should be paused while an alarm is running...

title: Crash + wiped all settings/etc.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Yesterday evening AntennaPod crashed during a manual feed update and when I went back in everything was gone! "You haven't subscribed to any feeds yet". Opening a file manager, I see that Android/data/de.danoeh.antennapod/ still looks good (so I made a copy of it!). The files/media/ directories still contain podcasts that I have downloaded, and the files/cache/ directories still contain all the feed-\* files.

1) Is there a way in which I can get AntennaPod to recreate the settings, etc, or should I just go ahead and add everything back in manually?

2) Where are the settings files stored that tell AntennaPod what I'm subscribed to, etc?

I have Update interval set to Manual, and I manually update feeds several times a day. Every couple of days or so, the app crashes during an update, usually if I try to do other operations within the app at the same time. I just go back in and retry and all is fine.

Thanks! -Ross

title: Feature request: pause and resume playback during voice navigation
body: I have used Google Listen from when I got my Android phone to when the Google Reader service was discontinued.  I tried BeyondPod and AntennaPod before the service ended and decided to stick with AntennaPod.  They are both good, but one is free and open source :)  The only feature I really miss now that I am using AntennaPod is that Google Listen would pause and resume playback during voice navigation.  I think this would be a great convenience feature to add.  I am willing to make a donation.

title: Enable or disable auto-download for individual feeds
body:
This addresses issue #212.

For lack of a better place, I put the option into the `FeedInfoActivity`. The setting only takes effect if auto-download is enabled globally. The default for each individual feed is to allow auto-downloads.

title: Feature Request: Add local SD card folder
body:
I've got a bunch of downloaded audio files on my phone's SD card: podcast episodes that are not available in their feeds anymore. It would be great to be able to create a "feed" by pointing AntennaPod to that specific folder on the SD card.

(Sorry if this is a duplicate, can't seem to find the search function anymore on GitHub, likely fallout from when the GH issues search was "leaking" passwords?)

title: Crash if file is moved
body:
Here is a way to crash AntennaPod 100% of the time:
1. From the file manager, open an mp3 file with AntennaPod, start reading.
2. Quit AP (completely, either by killing the process or by rebooting the device).
3. Move the file
4. Try to start AP: it will crashes 100% of the time.
One workaround is to put back the file, but it may not be possible in some cases. Example: someone gives you a SD card, you listen to some music or podcast. Then you turn off the phone to give back the SD card, when you start AP again you have no way to prevent it from crashing.
Tested on my smartphone with Android 4.1.2.

title: Invoking Episodes | Organize Que causes crash on BB10
body: I just updated to 0.9.7.4 for my BB Z10 and now when ever I try to reorder pod cast episodes AntennaPod crashes.  Also updating pod casts also crashes some of the time.

title: Use NineOldAndroid compatibility library for animations
body:
This fixes the crashes on pre-Honeycomb devices when entering the
Organize Queue activity (Fixes #223)

title: FR: let rewind & forward buttons also skip through episode playlist
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Currently they are only used rewind or forward within an episode. In a use-case, where the "continuous play"-option is disabled, it is therefore unnecessarily click-intensive to play an episode again or to load the next one in the playlist.

Please make the buttons also have the function of skipping to the next or previous episode, for example by long-pressing.

Thanks and greetings!

title: Feature Request: Autoresume on plug-in
body:
I want to request a feature, to have a configuration-box to decide if I want to automatically resume my podcast when pulling my plug back in.
I often hear podcasts when Im walking through the city but sometimes get interrupted. Then I just take the plug out so the episode gets stopped automatically. But after the interruption it doesn't resume when I plug it back in.

title: Feature request: Enhanced Sleep-Timer
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I think it would be great, if the sleep-timer wouldn't just stop playing, it should fade out.
And it happens, that the sleep-timer stops the podcast but I'm not sleeping yet. Therefor there should be something like the Snooze-function from alarm-clocks just inverted. 

I'm thinking of this: 
The sleep-timer starts fading out and I'm pressing a button (the hardware volume buttons would be predestined) and the volume is faded in to the former level and the sleep timer is set for 15 minutes (e.g.).

title: Upgrade ActionbarSherlock and ViewPager to latest maven central versions
body:
- Pull ActionbarSherlock and ViewPager apklibs from maven central.
- Upgrade AntennaPod to use latest version of ActionbarSherlock
- ForceOverflow theme no longer available in ActionbarSherlock

This makes it a bit easier to build AntennaPod locally instead of having to pull in sub modules.   The drag-sort-listview apk project doesn't seem to be maintained by the author any more, so you may want to host your own maven repo with this module and add the repository to the build.  In order to get this submodule to work, it's maven plugin version needed to be upgraded to 3.6.0.  I have that maintained in the following branch.

https://github.com/kingargyle/drag-sort-listview/tree/upgrade-to-3.6.0

If you hae the drag-sort-listview deployed locally already there build branch linked above isn't needed.

title: Enable Fast Forward and Rewind keys on Google TV remotes.
body: This enables the Fast Forward and Rewind keys on the google tv remote or any device that supports the appropriate keyboard codes.  If pressed it will jump ahead by 10 seconds or go back by 10 seconds.

title: Check file size after download
body:
This commit may address symptoms seen in #187 and #197 where
AntennaPod did not flag incomplete downloads as failed.

title: Flush BufferedOutputStream correctly
body:
This ensures that IOException due to writes are thrown in the main
code path instead of the exceptional code path.  Specifically for
HttpDownloader this ensures that IOUtils.closeQuietly does not swallow
a failed write.

title: Organize queue makes FC in 0.9.7.4
body:
The organize queue fetarure in 0.9.7.4 is broken.

If one tryes to Organize queue the app returns FC

Im using CyanogenMod 7.1

title: Virtual lists
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Please consider using virtual lists:
- new episodes
- downloaded episodes
- available for download
- unplayed
- partially played
- video
- audio

title: Promote DownloadError to enum for type-safety
Moving the time index circle or pressing skip forward at the end of an episode crashes AntennaPod.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
1. Play an episode
2. Skip almost to the end, when there's a few seconds left.
3. Continuously press the forward button. If tapped 3-4 times AntennaPod crashes.

Alternatively.
1. Play an episode
2. Skip almost to the end, when there's a few seconds left.
3. When the time index circle has reached the end of the episode, pull it back and it will occasionally crash.

title: Settings, playback history and downloads all go back to Podcasts view when back is pressed

title: Flattr queue
body:
These two patches implement a queue for pending flattrs whenever no internet connection is available. All pending items are flattred when the next thing is flattred and an internet connection is available.

I would consider this a first step towards implementing danieloeh/AntennaPod#87

The second patch creates a new flattr_queue table in the database and uses it to store the items to be flattred. This bumps the DATABASE_VERSION to 9.

Items in the table (CREATE TABLE FlattrQueue (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, feedItem INTEGER, feed INTEGER)) may either be a pending flattr to a feedItem (feedItem nonzero, feed is ignored), a feed (feeditem must be zero/NULL) or to AntennaPod itself (both feedItem and feed are zero).

title: Atom feeds with multiple enclosures: wrong(?). file downloaded
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
The Atom specification permits multiple files - one possible use for this is to do away with separate feeds for each podcast media format and include all available formats in a single feed.

In this case, AntennaPod appears to simply download whatever format (that is recognized) is last in the list. I created a test "feed" (valid single-entry atom xml file) with the media enclosures in the same format order I use for HTML5 audio <source> tags (i.e. preferred first). When the legacy mp3 format is last in the list, AntennaPod downloads the mp3 (skipping over the Ogg Vorbis version and the two other formats that it presumably doesn't recognize [opus and speex]). If I move the Ogg Vorbis version to the end of the list, the .ogg file is downloaded instead.

Short term: I would have expected it to instead default to the FIRST one (on the assumption that the "preferred" formats would be put first in the feed by the feed author, the same way users of the <audio> HTML5 tag do).

Long term (feature request): some sort of selection interface allowing download of any or all enclosures in at Atom entry (in addition to different formats of the same podcast media, multiple enclosures might also include "supporting media" such as diagram images, "show notes" text or pdf files, audio in different spoken languages, etc.)

The static single-entry Atom "feed" that I'm using for testing currently may be found here: http://blinky.dogphilosophy.net/atomtest.xml

  On the other hand I can spare a few taps when my "organising" is limited to sorting by media type.
- I could not find any protection for queue.  How can I make sure, that no other thread modifies queue/database while I am in the middle of sorting? One case I can think of is at the end of playback deleting first entry from the queue.  Is there any locking mechanism I could use?

title: Variable Speed Playback
body:
Adding variable speed playback to the service.  This doesn't include any GUI functionality yet, as I feel like how that is implemented could be a bit more contentious.  I'll (or somebody else can) add that separately.

Explanation of changes:
The com.aocate stuff is a Presto client library that reimplements the MediaPlayer API while adding variable speed playback.  Unfortunately, it only provides audio.  Since I didn't want two different PlaybackService classes (one for audio, one for video) both doing mostly the same stuff, I created an interface called IPlayer that has all of the methods of the current MediaPlayer.  I then subclassed the aocate MediaPlayer as AudioPlayer and the android MediaPlayer as VideoPlayer, both implementing the IPlayer interface. They're essentially wrappers of their supertypes so that I could keep a consistent interface.

Since we can't reuse the same MediaPlayer object for audio and video files, I made a few additional changes to the PlaybackService to use a different MediaPlayer object for every file being played.

Both MediaPlayer classes have their own nested interfaces that both expect their own type.  In order to not duplicate callback code (i.e., one interface that takes com.aocate._.MediaPlayer, and one that takes android._.MediaPlayer, but otherwise have the exact same code), I added a DuckType class to essentially force the IPlayer interface onto those classes at runtime.  I adapted the class from here: http://thinking-in-code.blogspot.com/2008/11/duck-typing-in-java-using-dynamic.html

title: More powerful waiting list

This process could be enhanced with some ideas:

body:
Hi! Thanks for AntennaPod!

The second patch will change the feed list to show the most recent episode's date instead of the feed's last update time (which is the same for all feeds, anyway).

These patches will require a translation update.

Hope you like it.

title: Resume failed downloads
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body: It would be cool, if dropped downloads (mostly due to no connectivity) could be resumed and not downloaded completely again.

title: Make removal of queued items undoable
body:
When scrolling the list in the `OrganizeQueueActivity`, items can easily be removed from the list by accident (this happened to me several times). And, if your queue is pretty full, it can be difficult to find those items in order to add them back.

This branch adds an UndoBar like the one from the official GMail app based on Roman Nurik's [UndoBar](https://plus.google.com/u/0/+RomanNurik/posts/RA9WEEGWYp6).

One problem with this implementation could be that in response to the removal of the item, the `FeedManager` might delete the item's media and start auto-downloading new episodes. These actions can currently not be undone. Maybe it would make sense to just remove the item and schedule the cleanup and auto-download for when the user leaves the activity.

title: Queue reordering according to specific criteria
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Certain users (e.g. those in issues #132 and #158) are reporting that they like to listen to shorter episodes first, or those from specific podcasts, or to newer ones.

It could be useful to have an option in the queue menu to reorder the queue according to any of these criteria, either automatically or on demand.

title: Reorder the Network settings
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
This issue is related to #135. A small reordering of the Network settings could make them clearer and avoid unwanted 3G usage. I think the Network settings should be as follows:

AUTOMATIC UPDATE
- Both on WiFi and 3G.
- Only on WiFi.
- Never update automatically (selected by default).

UPDATE INTERVAL (greyed out if automatic update is enabled)
- 1 hour / 2 hours / 4 hours / 8 hours / 12 hours / 24 hours.

AUTOMATIC DOWNLOADING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES
- Both on WiFi and 3G.
- Only on WiFi (selected by default).
- Never download enqueued episodes automatically.

AUTOMATIC STREAMING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES
- Checkbox: stream on 3G if it's their turn to play (unchecked by default).

EPISODE CACHE
- 10 episodes / 20 episodes / 40 episodes / 60 episodes / 80 episodes / 100 episodes.

WiFi FILTER
- Checkbox: treat unselected networks as if they were 3G.
- Checkboxes: list of known networks.

There are several advantages to this:

Data usage can be set more easily because you can set what the app can or cannot do while on 3G (and on WiFi) in a single field, without the need for an extra checkbox (as opposed to the "mobile updates" checkbox in the current version).

All related options are together, and unrelated ones are separate: the automatic update setting is next to the update interval, but far from the WiFi filter (because the latter affects several other things).

Last but not least, the "Automatic streaming of enqueued episodes" checkbox allows us to have a single action instead of the highly overlapping "Download" and "Enqueue", which is covered in #135.

title: AntennaPod fails to parse the website links for some feeds
body:
When a feed contains links to alternate feeds like in the example below, the last alternate link will override the website link, because the feed parser fails to check the link's MIME-Type.

``` xml
<link>http://einschlafen-podcast.de</link>
<atom:link rel="self" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast (aac))" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/aac/" />
<atom:link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast)" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/mp3/" />
<atom:link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast (Opus))" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/opus/" />
```

title: Issue #109 (feature request) - Display metadata on bluetooth devices that support AVRCP 1.3 and higher
body: This code adds the functionality described in issue #109. I tested these changes on my own bluetooth device.

title: Cleanup/Auto-Delete missing
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
HI,
I find there is one feature missing, that would make AntennaPod perfect and I believe it would be very easy to implement.

An option to either globally or on a per feed level to set:
- to keep only the last X episodes (e.g. keep only last 3 episodes and auto-delete older ones)
- to delete episodes older than X days (e.g. clean out old ones after 7 days, 30 days, etc)
- to keep all episodes (as it does now)

BeyondPod has this feature implemented, so have all PC-based podcatchers I have ever used (e.g. gpodder). With that implemented, one could run AntennaPod in fire-and-forget mode, without having to take care of deleting old content manually.

title: Problems with new interface (0.9.7+)
body:
Hi there,

Version 0.9.7 was unusable but *.7.2 is much nicer.

But the new interface still has some issues:
- **Titles in lists are shorted**: That's not just a problem of podcast with stupid episode titles (like "episode 45: something about the topic"), but also of podcast with complex topics ("Maskierte Mykotoxine - "). And maybe a problems for languages with longer words or compounds. 
- **Play/Pause/forward/-Buttons are tiny and don't use the given space**: In older Version the big Play/Pause-Button was VERY helpful. The button should be bigger and all buttons together should use the space efficiently.
- **It's hard to go from Cover to shownotes**: Thats really annoying, if you have a phone with a big screen or a short thumb its impossible to change between cover and shownotes. Please (re-)enable swipe there or make the whole "title area" (in the player) clickable, instead of just the little picture.
- **Remember state of cover  shownotes**: If you change from cover to shownotes and lock your phone antennapod will display the cover, or if you go to the playlist and then back to the player. Thats really annoying. (\ .o.)\   And please the position of the shownotes, so you don't have to scroll AGAIN if you where in the playlist and the shownotes are "scrolled back".
- **Global Sleeptimer**: The Sleeptimer should be reachable via GUI from everywhere (playlist, player episode, details, podcast list) and also be global. Now: If you say 30 min in the sleeptimer and your episode ends after 10 min the sleeptime disappears: (_)
- **Playlist jumps to the start**: We had this bug several versions ago. So: If you play number 10 in the playlist and the episode ends, antennapod jumps to number 1 in the playlist, not 11 (or 10 which would be away) .

But at all the new interface is more efficient. I don't tap as often as before. 

Greetings and sorry for this heap of bugs.
lof

title: "Mark as unread" vanished from long-press menu
body: It's still possible to mark an episode as read in the long press menu, but I couldn't find a way to mark a read episode as unread. Is it still possible but moved somewhere else or has the function been removed?

title: Register as RSS reader
body:
Thank you for your fantastic program. I use FindCast (iTunes search) to search for podcasts. Unfortunately, I cannot integrate it with Antennapod: When I click 'Open RSS' Antennapod is no option.

Could you register Antennapod as RSS reader?

title: Fix date format parsing
body:
I came across this bug because "Waiting List" was not sorted properly. Then i realized it was a date parsing problem with some feeds.

Short year format specification works in both cases. Long year didn't. You can check docs if you want:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html#applyPattern(java.lang.String)

The code has been tested with both types of year spec:
- Long format like "2013", which worked both before and after the patch. Eg: http://feeds.feedburner.com/droidcast/
- Short format like "13", which parsed nonsense timestamps (literally year 13 A.D.) before patch and now works. Eg: http://www.ivoox.com/portada-ivoox_fh.xml

title: Allow addition of local files to queue
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I mainly use AntennaPod to listen to podcasts I subscribed to, but from time to time I also listen to mp3 files I have on my SD card (an old podcast which closed but made all its archives available).

So I suggest the following feature: **allowing user to add local files to the queue**, these files being stored locally.
I see different ways to do this:
- Manually, the user would browse to a directory, then select one or several files to add to the queue (selecting several files should be possible).
- Allowing the addition of a new kind of feed by giving a local directory: AntennaPod would check this directory to see if files have been added, and then treat them as a classic feed.

I know it is possible to open a file with AntennaPod from the file manager, but this way does not allow one to build a listening list (the queue) with episodes both from classic feeds and from local files.

title: Option to hide Queue and Play-list
body:
Hey,

since I (and I guess most of the people) just download and update their feeds on wifi, the submenus Playlist and Queue under Episodes is obsolete since queue is just used for the few seconds it needs to download the podcasts.

So I suggest to have an and option in the settings menu to hide the categorys. Im not sure if someone needs it at all.

title: Develop pq
label: [Label(name="feature request"), Label(name="needs info"), Label(name="needs work")]
body:
Changes to allow for priority based sorting of the playback queue, useful for playing daily 'newsbite' podcasts before others.

Merged changes into develop branch and added an extra option for the auto download code.

title: Auto-download and auto-enqueue should be separated
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I love having the new auto-download feature, but I find that the auto-enqueuing of auto-downloaded podcasts is a bit too aggressive. I like being able to create a playlist from the available podcasts. While I might be interested in a podcast in general, certain episodes may not strike my fancy, and I like being able to leave them out of the playlist. But with the new auto-downloading, I don't seem to have that ability.

I had only used AntennaPod for a few days before this update, but I remember there being a setting to enqueue podcasts when they were downloaded. This allowed me to see a list of available podcasts in the "Waiting List" section, and then add specific ones of them to the "Queue" section as they interested me.

I like auto-downloading, though, so what seems ideal to me is for podcasts to be auto-downloaded into the "Waiting List," but allow for manual enqueuing -- possibly by returning the option to enable/disable enqueuing downloaded podcasts.

I hope that makes sense. I really think AntennaPod is great! Thanks for all your hard work.

title: Choosing a data folder should ask for moving existing data
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
> As a user I want to move all my existing data to another folder

AFAICT changing the data folder doesn't move existing data.

title: Configuration per podcast
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
> As a user I would like to define different settings for some podcasts.

For example, I don't want to auto-download some of the podcasts I have subscribed to.

body:

The display on the bottom shows the correct played time.

title: Large Application Icon Needed
body: I have installed AntennaPod on a 9" tablet with Full HD resolution.  The default UI blows  application icons to about 1/4 of the tablet hight. That is about 256x256px...  The present icon scaled to this size looks awful.  I would suggest including a few larger bitmaps or SVG of the original (if Anroid understands SVG icons, of course).

title: Merge the Download and Enqueue buttons
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
If you visit an unqueued, undownloaded episode and click Stream, the episode starts playing and is moved to the top of the queue. But this doesn't happen with the Download and Enqueue actions.

If you click Download, the app downloads it but it doesn't add it to the bottom of the queue. If you click Enqueue, the app is added to the bottom of the queue but it isn't downloaded.

Downloading an episode should always mean its getting added to the queue (and vice versa if you're on a WiFi) so these two buttons should be merge into a single Enqueue button.

However, after entering the credentials, the page redirects to an flattr4j://de.danoeh... URL, which Chrome seemingly can't handle, resulting in an error 302 (net::ERR_UNKNOWN_URL_SCHEME).

title: Episodes should auto-queue in order oldest to newest (or allow configuring the order)
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
The current behavior seems to queue newest episodes first, which can be a little bit confusing/jarring when you finish listening to recent episodes, and suddenly jump backward in time.

I imagine that not all users would prefer doing it this way, it might be best to have this configurable, possibly with a per-feed option and a global default.

I see two primary listening scenarios:
1. The user wants to listen to every episode on the subscription in the order which they come  out.
2. The user has more feeds than can all be followed, and wants to listen to whatever is recent. In this case, older episodes could eventually fall off the list

I suppose there is also the potential for wanting to listen to everything, _and_ wanting to hear them newest to oldest, but I'm not sure what the prevalence for that is (and maybe I am actually in the minority).

This could work nicely with #71 as well, with the priority taking precedence, then date-time ordering.

title: add support for import feeds from google reader
body: for user migrate from google listen

title: Ability to use any media linked in a post
label: [Label(name="wontfix")]
body:
The podcast "En Flux Libre"[1] cannot be used through AntennaPod, although they do have the OGG files directly linked into the RSS[2].
1. Home page: http://www.enfluxlibre.org/
2. RSS: http://www.enfluxlibre.org/?q=rss.xml

It would be nice if AntennaPod could retrieve all/any audio file linked and use them as the actual podcast(s).

title: Check for new episodes automatically
body:
I have been trying the test version for a couple days and it seems to check for new episodes, add them to the queue and download them automatically alright when I press the Refresh button.

The only problem I see is that I have to press the button. The idea behind making everything automatic is that the user can add the podcasts he wants and forget about AntennaPod, and the app will still do its thing and serve him new episodes in a silver plate.

To manage that the app shouldn't wait until the user opens it and presses Refresh. It should keep working in the background, checking for new episodes every so often (Daily? When the phone is charging and on WiFi?) and if it finds them, enqueue and download them automatically.

And of course then let the user know, which is issue #122.

title: Show a progress bar for all downloaded items
label: [Label(name="feature request"), Label(name="needs info")]
body:
In the new test version of AntennaPod all enqueued items are downloaded automatically, but they don't show a progress bar until you start listening to them:

![Bar](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244801/ad0382e0-8a6e-11e2-9613-a20bdd54fd34.png)

They also show the word "Length" before they play time, but the ones you have started listening don't. I'm not sure whether or not this is intentional, but it looks like a UI inconsistency to me.

title: "Listened" and "Downloaded" as two tabs inside History.
label: [Label(name="wontfix")]
body:
Right now the Overflow menu has two different entries for History-related items: "Playback History" and "Downloads"

The menu could be freed up if they were shown as tabs inside a "History" section, which would only take one slot in the menu.

![History](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244768/b4b7a954-8a6d-11e2-90e4-9c7ce72684a1.png)

Additionally, it would make sense to show that item in a dropdown instead of the Overflow menu, which is shown in issue #125. That way it wouldn't even clutter Overflow at all.

title: Swipe episodes away
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
This suggestion is included in a couple other issues (e.g. #125) but I think it's worth having its own issue.

Now that episodes are added to the waiting list and the playing queue automatically, we need an easy way to dismiss the ones that don't interest us. Swiping away is the quickest and handiest way, and the one many Google apps (e.g. Gmail) are favouring:

![Swipe](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244618/0d5d9a26-8a6b-11e2-9b03-788207dcea61.png)

![Swipe2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244621/1110244a-8a6b-11e2-9332-d8332db43f23.png)

The user would just have to flick their finger to the left or right, and the episode is dismissed. Unlistened episodes (that is, those the user never even started listening) would be deleted and forgotten, and listened ones (even partially listened ones) would be skipped and go to the History.

It could even be used at the top of the queue (that is, on the current episode) to skip the current episode and start listening to the next one, which would be an easy way to implement Skip without having to use extra buttons or UI elements.

title: Use a dropdown instead of tabs
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Here's a couple mockups of AntennaPod if it used a dropdown to move between sections instead of tabs:

![Dropdown](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244538/7dcedcc8-8a68-11e2-93a1-4ab5c43ddf8d.png)

![Dropdown2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244563/55e5cf68-8a69-11e2-8c70-b5b0bbce67fe.png)

I have several reasons to think that this would be better than we have now:
- First, it would save space. Once you have subscribed to the desired podcasts (and once auto-download and auto-enqueue are implemented) the user shouldn't really have a lot of reasons to switch between sections. He will probably spend most of the time in the Episodes section, so I think that the saved space will become more important than being able to change sections quickly.
- Second, it would allow to move the History section into the dropdown. Which, being a section and not an action, I think would make more sense than having it inside the overflow menu.
- Third and most important, it would allow to swipe episodes away. Unwanted episodes could be dismissed very quickly, with the flick of a finger. Which will become very important once new episodes are added automatically to the waiting list. It's important to note that swiping away is impossible with the current approach because horizontal movement just changes sections.

title: Beginers
body: Im a begginer in making android app. I was trying to load this on eclipse but there are many errors. I've already followed all the things in the wiki. Is there a prerequisites on what do I need to download for my SDK to work?

title: Fixed regression, issue #96
body:
The regression came with the use of AndroidHttpClient, where URLs are strictly validated.
The fix uses RedirectHandler to rewrite/fix broken URLs in case of redirection. AndroidHttpClient does not allow setting of RedirectHandler, therefore DefaultHttpHandler has been put in place.

Potential issues:
- DefaultHttpHandler implements the same interface as AndroidHttpClient, but does not support close() call (It seems that newer API will support it).  I assume, that GC is able to deal with it.

title: Show notification after auto-downloading items.
label: [Label(name="wontfix")]
body: After AntennaPod automatically downloads and enqueues a number of episodes, it would be useful to have a notification that reads "There are X new items ready to listen" and has a "Play" button to start listening right away.

title: Reserve some space to cache enqueued items and to keep listened ones.
body:
Several issues suggest using auto-download. In order to have that we need the app to do the following:
- Devote some of the phone's memory to store podcasts when they are added to the playing queue.
- Erase already listened episodes in order to make room for new ones.

This brings two problems:
- There needs to be a way to decide how much space is given.
- Episodes shouldn't be erased IMMEDIATELY after being listened, because if you like an episode and want to listen to it again you would have to use additional data. As a result, there needs to be a way to decide how much space is given to listened episodes.

Therefore, two settings are needed:
- Disk space for cached episodes (by default: 10%).
- Disk space for listened episodes (by default: 5%).

If you had a phone with 8GB memory AntennaPod would automatically download and enqueue new episodes until they reached 800MB, at which point it would stop. Additionally, listened episodes would be kept until they reached 400MB, at which point the older ones would be deleted from the memory.

A user with a lower-end phone but really into podcasts could use those settings in order to devote more space.

title: Implement a "Share" button
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I would like to have a "Share" button that lets me use Android's sharing capabilities, so that I can use social networks, mail and so on to share an episode (or podcast) with my friends.

Implementing deep linking (http://googleplusplatform.blogspot.com.es/2012/11/deep-linking-from-android-apps.html) would also be a nice addition, because it would encourage said friends to use AntennaPod to listen to them.

title: Remove the "Downloads" screen.
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
If #116 is implemented there won't be any need for a Downloads screen. It will be easy to spot episodes being downloaded, because they will always be either in the playing queue or in the top spots of the waiting list.

If you give them a "downloading" icon and a download progress bar (similar to the progress bar in half-listened items) seeing what downloads are taking place will be so simple right on the main screen that Downloads will be able to be removed, thus simplifying the interface and without losing anything.

title: Simplify the long-press menu
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
This issue is related to #116 because it implies the workflow suggested there.

When you long-press an episode you get a lot of options that could be simplified:

![Screenshot_2013-03-07-16-50-09](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/232777/7ef0850a-8740-11e2-9aaf-15b31a01ae58.png)

In that screenshot:
- "Remove" deletes the file but leaves the episode in the playing queue.
- "Remove from queue" returns the file to the waiting list, but keeps the file in the phone.

If #116 is implemented neither of the above would make sense because being in the queue imply being downloaded, and the other way around. But we do need:
- A "Remove" option that completely deletes the file and makes the app forget about the episode. This should apply to items in the queue, waiting list or history. Also, in addition to a long-press action this could be triggered by swiping the episode away.
- An "Add to queue" option that takes items from the waiting list or the history and adds them to the bottom of the playing queue. Also, of course, sets them to be downloaded ASAP.
- Optionally some "Return to waiting list" and "Move to history" options for items in the queue. I don't think I would want these, though: once you move an episode to the queue you probably won't want to move it back unless you've lost your interest and don't want to listen to it anymore, in which case it would be simpler to just swipe it away and be done with it.
- "Mark as read" removes the "new" banner.
- "Mark as unread" adds it again.

I find these largely irrelevant and, unless I've misunderstood their function, I don't think they're worth two slots in the long-press menu.

Therefore, if you long-press an item in the playing queue I think that you should get these options:
- Play, which moves the episode to the top and starts playing it.
- Remove, already explained.

And if you long-press an item in the waiting list or history you should get:
- Play.
- Remove.
- Add to playing queue, which adds it to the bottom of the queue.

In addition to that, It could be useful to show these options as buttons on the bottom bar so that you can apply them to several items at once. Here's a quick mockup:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/233013/00638e92-8747-11e2-8fd0-dd6cf3057409.png)

As you see the mockup shows several selected items and three buttons at the bottom bar, which correspond to Play, Remove and Add to queue.

title: Try a card interface
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
This suggestion is related to #79 and #116 because it uses a single queue and doesn't distinguish between new and old episodes, but downloaded and undownloaded.

I think that switching to a card interface would make the queue look cleaner and make it easier to delete unwanted episodes:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/226933/111fa5a4-8648-11e2-97a1-1d5f7791bdfa.png)

As you see, each episode is separated from the rest and all the relevant data appears in a clean way: you can see the episode's title and channel, as well as duration and progress (except for undownloaded episodes, which show their size instead).

Similarly to #79, the episode being played is shown at the top of the queue. Its card is a bit bigger than the rest and shows some extra data. It also has a bigger proggress bar that lets you scroll through the episode.

As specified in #116 all new episodes are added to the bottom of the "Undownloaded" list. As you listen to the ones at the top they get deleted, making room, and the ones at the top of "Undownloaded" are downloaded and moved to the bottom of the "Downloaded" list, so that you know that you can listen to them without using any mobile data.

You can browse through the whole list and if any particular episodes don't attract you you can simply swipe them away and make room for new ones, which is one of the main benefits of the card interface.

If you're browsing through the Undownloaded episodes and you see one that you like you can long-press it and choose to "Play" it (which moves it to the top of the Downloaded list and starts playing it right away) or "Download" it (which moves it to the bottom of the Downloaded list).

title: Instead of "Queued" and "New", use "Downloaded" and "Undownloaded"
body:
I don't think I have ever fully grasped what a "New" episode is. I guess it's new because it's been added recently? How recently? When does a new episode stop being new? Do I need to listen to it for it to become old, or does it automatically after some time?

This suggestion is kind of related to #79 in that new and old episodes are added to the same list. The suggestion is to do away with the concept of "New" episodes and replace it with a concept much easier to grasp: "Downloaded" vs. "Undownloaded" episodes.

![49d18e40-8511-11e2-9a30-e8ca5e71401c](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/226725/5f90703c-863f-11e2-9f05-a23eed6ed085.png)

The idea is that you have only one queue, and all new episodes are added to the bottom of that queue. The ones at the top are downloaded automatically when you have a WiFi connection, and then deleted after you listen to them in order to make room for new ones.

That way you always have fresh new episodes ready to be listened without having to use 3G data, and you never have to worry about which ones you download because the application takes care of that by itself.

Why separate downloaded episodes from undownloaded ones, then, if it's just one list? To let you know which ones you can listen to without using your data connection. That way, if there is one episode that attracts you in the "Undownloaded" section you can download it while you're at home, which will add it to "Downloaded" and let you listen to it on the go.

Maybe even separate "skip & keep" and "skip & delete" entries.

title: Auto-dequeue
body:
I'd like to request an "Auto-dequeue" option, please, that automatically removes an episode from the queue once it has completed playing.

This is different from the "Auto-delete" option in that the episode shouldn't be deleted from my cache when it is dequeued.  Keep it in the cache in case I want to listen/view it again.  Only delete it from cache at a later cache-expiration period, such as 7 days.

I loved this feature on ACast: when somebody starts to talk, I just disconnect the headphones directly in my jacket's pocket, and when they're done, I just push the jack back in, and playback resumes. With AntennaPod I can do the disconnecting to stop, but to restart the podcast I need to get my phone out, unlock it, and click on the play button. Even less handy when I'm on my bike ;)

title: AntennaPod starts playing audio on its own
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
If I've been listening to a podcast and then pause it, sometimes at some point several minutes (or even hours) later AntennaPod will start playing the podcast all on its own. This isn't just pocket activation, it happens when it's sitting on my desk, or when I'm using it in the car. The usual situation is that I've been listening in the car or on headphones, I'll pause the playback, and then it will spontaneously start again a while later. This seems to happen regardless of whether something was plugged into the headphone jack during playback and both when playback has been paused normally and when it's been paused because the audio cable was unplugged.

This happens in 0.9.6.4, and in the previous version. Please let me know what I can do to help via logs, etc. Sadly, I can't figure out how to reproduce the behavior, but it happens several times a week.

I'm experiencing this issue on my Tmo Galaxy S3 running Cyanogenmod 10.0.0-d2tmo (Android 4.1.2).

title: Files from failed downloads are never deleted.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
When a download fails, the app leaves the file from the download on the sd-card. When the download is retried, it creates a new file with "-1" attached to the filename. If that fails again, it proceeds with "-2" and so on. 
Only the last file (the download that finally worked) will be recognized by the app and can be deleted afterwards. There is no possibility to delete those other files from within the app.

title: Feature request: More button functionality in external player
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
I listen to a few podcasts that do some heavy news up front, then more discussion on the back.  Sometimes I like to jump to my next podcast (and optionally delete the one I just listened to) after the news segment.  While driving/working, its important to be able to do this with a single touch.  I think something like a 'next track' button would be very useful on the external player.

Also, is there any way we can change the 30 second rewind?  I think a 10 second rewind (or a configurable amount) is pretty common in other players.  The rationale is for skipping ads.  I'll hear a lot of ads that run 30-90 seconds, and I often overshoot the ad by just a bit but I want to hear the discussion I missed without having to listen to the last 20 seconds of the ad.

title: Google Reader Integration
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
Let me start off by saying thank you for producing high quality open source software and sharing it with everyone. I have been wanting to mess with android app development for a while, and I have started hacking at your code to understand how things work. Anyways, I've been playing around with the Google Reader API in the hopes of adding (some level of) google reader functionality to AntennaPod. 

At the very least it would be trivial to get an OAuth2 token from Android and then access the OMPL for a particular label directly from google reader as an import option (I've already gotten this level of functionality working in a dummy app). This would be way easier than the current OMPL import functionality and would only require one extra permission (USE_CREDENTIALS or something). 

Taking the idea further, one could imagine using google reader as a full on sync target for all feeds and read/unread statuses. This isn't so much a feature request as a request to gauge interest. If there is interest in such a feature (I know that Issue #21 is sort of a request in this direction) and no one is working on it, I'd like to contribute. If not, I can just try to develop the changes in a fork that I'll use myself and won't submit to Google Play.

title: Stop service if not needed
body: Please consider stopping the service, when it is not needed. I.e. only manual updates and no headphone polling.

title: Appears to have issues with gzip encoded feeds.
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
EscapePod has recently updated their feeds to use gzip encoding on the feed results.

http://feeds.escapeartists.net/EscapePod

Looking at the results that come back thru the browser using Fiddler (http tracer) I see that the orginal URL redirects (302) to http://escapepod.org/feed/rss2 which redirects (301) to http://escapepod.org/feed/ all of these have HTTP header of Content-Encoding: gzip.

Looking at the downloaded feed in the cache directory I can see that the feed is still gzipped rather than unzipped to plain text.

Antenapod throws a "Download failed Unsupported Feed type: Invalid type"

Let me know of you want HTTP tracings or the gzipped feeds.

Regards

Stuart

title: Forward and Backward Buttons
body:
One feature that present in some podcast players, e.g. DoubleTwist, PocketCasts, etc., that I miss in AntennaPod is Forward and Backward Buttons, i.e. a button that skips ahead 30 seconds and one that skips behind 10 seconds.

In regards to the interface, I think PocketCasts actually nailed it by making the buttons large overlays on the image art. Clicking to the right of the image art skips ahead 30 seconds. Clicking to the left of the image art skips behind 10 seconds. It makes it much easier to use the buttons blindly.

title: Merge "New" and "Queue" tabs for easier use
label: [Label(name="feature request")]
body:
As a user, I don't really think of "new" episodes as opposed to "queued" ones. I just want to know what new stuff there is to hear, and operate the app while giving it as little thought as possible. I would AntennaPod's interface to reflect this.

I made a quick mockup that you can see here:

![podcast 2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/23233/8a471234-4a2d-11e2-88f2-5fd28272b456.png)

As you see there's still a "Feeds" tab, but the "New" and "Queued" tabs are replaced by a single "Episodes" one. The episode being played is at the top of it, with some control buttons.

Right below it are the episodes that have been downloaded and are ready to be listened. When the current episode ends, it goes to the History and is replaced by the first item in the list.

Old, listened items are removed automatically and make room for new ones to be downloaded (also automatically) and added to the list.

This way, supposing I have already subscribed to a selection of feeds that I like, I can keep listening to new episodes without ever worrying to check for new episodes, or having to download newer ones or reorder the list, or even ever leaving the "Episodes" screen.

As a user, I would only have to press "Play" to start listening and "Pause" to stop, and no further action would ever be required from me.

title: OPML import from DoggCatcher fails
body:
The OPML export that DoggCatcher makes puts the `<outline text="..." xmlUrl="..."/>` elements directly inside the `<opml version="1.1">` element, without a body or head.

While this should probably be a bug report against that app, I don't see why AntennaPod couldn't parse this invalid document; the option nodes are all that's important right?

If you agree, I'll almost definitely be able to write a patch.
